I could tell that not only was he used to working with large groups but with tight spaces.  As dishes started coming out for our party of 10, he was able to expertly move, combine, and find spots to keep food going on the lazy Susan.  Add the fact the drinks remained full the whole time in the chaotic atmosphere leads to one finely skilled server.  1 Star.Food - This the third time I'm mentioning the Peking Duck.  They bring it to your table, cut/carve it up, and then serve it up with steamed buns or pancakes.  I preferred the thin pancakes but it's nice to have an option.  What's great is that there's no bone, it's hot & fresh, and is the best Peking Duck I've had in DFW.  Definitely the best dish they have....and the most memorable.  The rest of the dishes were forgettable, including the mango shrimp that I couldn't decide if I should have eaten it hot or cold.  Bottom line is that while the one dish they made was the best I had in DFW, I can't recall anything else I really liked.  But best in DFW does carry a lot of weight.  1 Star.Will I Return? - When they move to a bigger place.  I feel Mr. Wok needs to be moved to a new, bigger space.  The old Pizza Hut is actually cool, but it's not claustrophobic friendly.  The Peking Duck is outstanding and is a no brainer to order.  I guess even if they stay put I'll still be a huge fan of this signature dish.   1/2 Star.My Yelp Rating Scale (Sum of all parts):1 Star - Atmosphere - Is it a cool dive?  Perhaps an upscale place?  No matter the type, atmosphere plays a big part and I'll give a star if I like it or thinks it has great charm.1 Star - Service - You can have a great meal with bad service.  But that's also what can make a five star joint drop to four.  It's important to the dining experience that service is great and on point.2 Stars - Food - I'll award up to two stars for the food, since this is the main reason we dine out.  Sometimes the extra star is given for value, but it's really all about the food.1 Star - Will I come back? - If I know for a fact I'll return, I'll give this a star. A place has to make an impression for me to return. Each Category can be given up to 1 star except food (2 stars) because I consider all these categories important to the overall dining experience.  I will sum them up to provide my final Yelp score.

Customer service here deserves a 3. Called in ahead to make a reservation and we had to wait an extra 30 minutes. I had to order my food ahead for the group so that when the seat us, the food would be ready. Once we were seated, we got all our food right away. The peking duck came in a little later. I gave this restuarant a 4 just because of the duck. One of the best ive had because it wasnt greasy or fatty at all. Very lean and it came with the pancakes and bao. Overall, good chinese food for DFW.

Another great Peking duck experience at Mr. Wok. Well worth the long drive and 45-minute wait for the freshly roasted bird with the crispiest of skins.Bonus: 2nd course with the bones is included, either soup or stir-fried with pickled cabbage. Yum!Pro Tip: Remember to bring your favorite adult beverage as it is BYOB with no corkage fee... The Tom Thumb store at the corner of 14th and Jupiter has a very nice selection of chilled wines and beers.Don't forget to tell Jack and Allison that the Deep Ellum Duo sent you! :)
Cheater! The 10% off discount from Dealmoon is just for Beijing duck not all, but the coupon indicates that it is for all dishes, and the food taste like crap!

Very small place, I don't think they deliver everything I try a new place I get the fried rice first the reason why? Because it's very hard to mess up that dish and I don't want to waste my money on more expensive dishes if they can't even get fried rice right. Well I must report that unfortunately they didnt,get the fried rice right
Loved owner Jake and waitress Eary.High quality very flavorful food. Tried crispy tangy beef and it was sweet and yummy. Packed

Best Peking Duck I have had stateside! There are many reviews on the duck so I want to recommend a few hidden gems.While some of these dishes sound super Americanized, I promise they are good.Eggplant in Garlic Sauce(option:+shredded pork): The way they cut their eggplant is very different. It comes in much smaller pieces so the flavour really sink in. Delicious! Mango Shrimp: I wish they have more shrimp in this dish but it has an interesting hot(fried shrimp) vs. cold(mango) silky taste.Stir Fry Bean Sprouts: I think this dish costs less than $5 and it is done very well. A very crispy veggie dish you just cannot put down.This place is tiny (I think no more than 10 tables), thus it is always packed. Definitely call ahead if you want to visit on the weekends.

Food was just okay. Shrimp fried rice contained very small, undeviened shrimp. I picked up to go. Fly in the area where I was getting food. Didn't seem to be the cleanest place. Waitress came from outside and assisted with bagging food without washing hands. Prices were reasonable is the only positive I had.

Two words: Peking duck. This is something you should definitely try. Cute little place in Plano. Usually busy on the weekends so make reservation if possible. This is also a great place for family dining. For additional entrees, try their mango shrimp and eggplant. Every option on the menu is quite satisfying especially when it comes with a good price.
The Peking duck and stir fry is amazing! I also would recommend the fried calamari! :) Jack and his team are always very pleasant and we come back for the great food and service!

Had a surprise birthday party here for my wife. They were very accomadating for the party. They gave a big enough table for thr entire party and small table for cake and alcohol (its BYOB). They appetizers were good especially the sampler platter. The peking duck was by far the best ever, it tasted like butter with the crispy skin and its succulant meat. They take the meat from the meat and make it into a soup or stir fry which is delicious. The customer service at this place was excellent. They were very accomadating and friendly. The owner working in the kitchen was very comforting however he greeted and took time to talk to us. There were pictures of celebrities on the including Troy Aikman. If this place is good enough for him then its good enough for me. I  am definitely coming back here.

Don't be fooled by the exterior, this former Pizza Inn in an older neighborhood houses a killer Asian restaurant! I was turned on to Mr Wok by a friend several years ago. We are now regulars. I have never had a bad dish there and the Peking Duck is a best ever. Pad Thai is great too. My wife loves the Fried Rice and since she orders it everywhere we go, I guess she'd know!The prices are very reasonable, even cheap for the quality. It's cheerfully BYOB which saves even more since my wife enjoys wine with her dinner.Word is out and this place gets very busy nearly any day of the week. Go early or expect a wait, but they do take reservations if you have 6+ people or order a duck. Duck is supposed to be ordered in advance but I've had good luck walking in and getting one early in the evening, they are so popular they make extras.You do have to understand the service. Not only is it almost always crowded and busy, but food comes out when it's ready rather than trying to serve everyone at the table at the same time. This may be a cultural difference and certainly works if you are sharing dishes at the table and does ensure each dish is fresh and hot, but if you are doing the each to his own order thing someone may get to watch everyone else eat for a while. Better to share and enjoy anyway, it's all going to be good!
the peking duck here has to be ordered in advance, but it's totally worth it. nothing like seeing your duck carved at the table right in front of you. my favorite dish here!

Quick update: the peking duck here is truly an AMAZING and incredibly flavorful experience. You must call ahead of time to reserve yourself a duck but it is a MUST! and its very filling! My husband and I have gone several times now and we always have leftovers to take home!

I definitely want to take my family here one day. We had the beggars chicken, Peking duck, combination Cantonese stir fry, and chocolate banana egg roll. You have to call 2 days ahead for the chicken and 1 day for the duck. The Cantonese stir fry isn't on the menu but we saw a picture of it on the wall.I've never seen food presented in this manner before. The chicken was stuffed with some rice/herbs and the chicken was baked for 22 hours in some bread. They let you "beat" the bread before they cut it open for you at the table. So everybody's in the restaurant will stare at you because of the noise. The duck is actually sliced in front of you where you can choose between either some tortilla or a bao (get the bao). They give you an option to use the remaining bones and meat to either make a stir fry or a soup. I didn't really like the chicken that much bc the duck was soo much better, but it was still delicious. The duck skin was so crispy! It comes with the typical dipping sauce and some green vegetable. The chicken was pretty moist that the meat easily pulled apart when you're digging into it.The stir fry had a tasty sweet sauce topped onto the crispy pan fried noodles. I would recommend the stir fry and Peking duck!The chicken was like $35, duck was $32, and stir fry was less than $8 bucks? The price is really cheap since they give you a large portion. I looked through the rest of the menu and I don't think i saw anything over 10 bucks. They have lunch specials for around 6 bucks!This place is BYOB. The waitress originally gave us the regular American menu but then the owner dropped off the Chinese menu that has more options to choose from.

Had the Sesame Chicken lunch special today!  Unbelievably priced ($6.22!) and I literally ate everything in the plate! Not even shredded lettuce garnish was left behind because of that sauce! The vast demographic of customers this place brings in speaks volumes for how loved this place is by almost everyone who's ever tried it.
Easily the best Chinese food we've had in Dallas. We had Peking duck and orange beef. Outstanding!

Always a great dining experience. Our server Alma was the best, having properly taken care of us and practically the whole restaurant as well. Full house on a Tuesday night which should tell you how good of a restaurant this is. Buff owner carved our duck and has an awesome personality. Not a single thing to say negative. It was all good and highly recommended. Good job Mr. Wok!

I really enjoyed my first visit tonight to Mr. Wok in Plano. I've heard very good things from friends & family and read excellent reviews. My cousin invited me to dinner for a very belated birthday dinner. It was a Friday night and quite busy. Our waiter David had a very large table & it took him awhile to greet us and bring us some water. Once he did we ordered appetizers and our entrees. First we had the edamame which is wonderful and has a nice smokey taste because it's tossed in a wok before it is served. I had a cup of hot & sour soup and the potstickers which were pan fried and delicious. For our entrees I had the sesame beef with fried rice and my cousin had the shrimp pad thai. I tasted it and it was very good, the sauce was very tasty. For dessert we shared the banana & chocolate filled spring rolls with caramel sauce. So delicious - yummy! Loved them :)David was a great waiter, very friendly, knowledgeable and prompt. The owner/chef also stopped by our table. He confirmed what we had earlier asked our waiter - whether they use msg or not. He said NO! I am thrilled as a very well known high end Chinese restaurant in west Plano still uses msg and have refused to make dishes without it for a close friend of mine who cannot consume anything with it, it gives her severe migraines and makes her quite ill. Thankfully we now have an excellent option so that we can all dine together. Highly recommend you try Mr. Wok. It's primarily a Chinese restaurant with some Thai and other Asian dishes. It is not a huge restaurant so go early or make a reservation. They're famous for their Peking duck which must be preordered as well as the Beggar's Chicken.  Hope to try those soon too.

This is by far my favorite place to eat. I try to get here at least once a week...it's not much to look at but they have phenomenal food and great prices. I would have never thought to eat Peking Duck but I tried it and I literally crave it all the time. I have had the 2nd course both stir fried and in the soup and I will say I prefer the soup but it is good either way. I really could ramble on and on about this place but long story short is that they are by far the best Asian restaurant I have ever been to. I would recommend this to everyone from the hardcore fan and the sesame chicken type fan. Have fun and tell Jack and Evelyn I said hello!

We just finished the best dinner we have had in a long time at Mr. Wok in Plano.  We had a group of seven and an early reservation (4:30 pm) so they gave us center seating with a big lazy Susan in the middle.  We called them yesterday to pre-order the Peking Duck.  We ordered 3 additional dishes in addition to the duck.  We had crispy beef, sesame chicken, Double wok seared, and sizzling seafood.  The Peking Duck carved table side was incredible.  Crispy skin with moist pieces of duck accented with scallions and hoisin sauce with either pancakes or buns (we ordered both).  All the other dishes were great as well, but the duck was the star.  We tried all three desserts; fried ice cream, fried chocolate banana, and fried banana.  All again were excellent.  Met the owner Jack and had a wonderful evening.  Now my new favorite restaurant.

Located in a former full service Pizza Hut (remember those?), you might not expect excellent Chinese cuisine, but you'd be very mistaken. This place just goes from strength to strength. Whether you come for the Peking Duck (24 hours notice) or the wok seared edamame or the salt & pepper shrimp or the... Well, you get the pic. Everything is quality here. Just go there. You won't be disappointed. Wait! Nevermind. It's hard enough getting in there as it is. Forget I wrote anything ;)

Peking duck here is very good and more traditional than most places. We came on a Saturday afternoon and it was not crowed which I like. Fried rice was good but the fried green beans and tofu was not. It had great flavor but came out to soft for my taste. Can't wait to come back and try the fish.

Best Chinese Food in DFW area! Great food and service... what more can you ask for? Must try dishes:-Peking duck (DUH) ... Oh yeah and you also have the option to get a soup or stir fry dish out of the leftover duck they don't use for the Peking duck entree! -Mango shrimp-Eggplant in garlic sauce (my personal fave)-Tofu with smoked salmonMake sure you make reservations a few days in advance and pre-order the Peking duck, if you want it. They get super packed for dinner, especially weekends. Enjoy!
I love this renovated pizza hut.  So cute and quaint.Fantastic food.  Surprisingly inexpensive for good service and food.

Service is great--everyone is really friendly to deal with!Out of their two major specialties, the Beggar's Chicken and the Peking Duck, my family and I had the Peking Duck. The Peking Duck was good--the duck was definitely fresh and tender, and the skin was really nice and crispy! I wouldn't say it's the best I've ever had, but it was definitely great. On the plus side, they take all the extra meat and bones and turn it into stir-fry (and I think there was another choice, but I can't remember what it is...), which was super tasty!However, the other food--eh, I'm not a big fan. Mr. Wok is a very typical Asian-Americanized Chinese restaurant. We ordered Crabmeat Soup, Sweet & Sour Tilapia, Fried Calamari, & Black Bean Chicken. None of it was... bad. But I didn't think the food here was worth it. It was very typically Americanized and very unauthentic for Chinese food (I mean, there were green peas in my soup and my fish, which you don't see in actual Chinese dishes...), and nothing specially tasty. I wouldn't mind coming back again--but for the Peking Duck alone, which was definitely enough to garner four stars (plus good service). And maybe I'll try the Beggar's, because apparently that's super good too. If you're looking for good Chinese, I would stick to their specialties and avoid the rest.

Busy busy busy even on a Wednesday. Peking duck (2), fried tofu, fried calamari and mango chicken.The wait staff really tried to accomodate everyone. Arrived at 6pm for reservations, within 30 minutes, all tables were busy and wait staff bustling all over. A+ for their hard work and effort.Peking ducks, om nom nom nom. Called earlier in the day for reservations and the 2 ducks. Ducks were served whole and then sliced at table. Make a mini duck burger with steamed buns or a wrap with the steamed pancakes. We had both! Duck was top notch quality. Juicy and super crispy skin. The leftover carcass could be stir fried in a hoisin/soy/green onion mixture so you can knaw what leftover meat was on there OR you can have a soup with bean thread noodles. Both was good!Fried tofu was silk tofu, lightly battered then fried. Tofu was soft and silky. Served with a peanut soy sauce. It's steaming hot so let it cool before eating.Fried calamari had the perfect seasoning and fried texture. Just the right amount of sweet and salty. So Delicious! The only con was maybe the quality of the calamari itself. The calamari, if really tasted, you will notice it's frozen calamari and may have been frozen for a little too long. But this doesn't stop us from ordering it everytime.Mango shrimp was a first for us. Served on lettuce in a fried wonton? bowl. Shrimp was battered and deep fried, then tossed in a mayo type of sauce with fresh sweet mangos. It tasted pretty interesting and good. Flavor not too strong to overpower the mango flavor. Not sure if it's a reorder item though.Byob! If u forget a bottle opener, they'll have one!

Great food fantastic service I have only come for dinner with the family on a week night so we never have a problem getting seated several of great dishes Mongolian beef and hunan beef are great choices from the dinner specials the come with fried or steamed rice and an egg roll or soup. I believe the place is byob.

Possibly my favorite Chinese place in DFW along with YAO FUZI.actually the only thing i want/need is the peking duck. ive only gotten duck like 7-10 times in my life and im freakin asian. i dont usually get it because either a) its greasy as hell and b) VERY VERY boney. they take care of both of these because they used compressed air during the roasting process underneath the skin to render out a ton of the fat so your not just eating fat with some meat. also some great guys come over and slice it all up for you so that you dont have to work so hard at it. the service was EXTREMELY friendly and you see why asians are there. thats how you know an asian restaurant was good. decent crowd even on a friday.i plan to try the beggars chicken next time but it requires 2 day call in. GO TO THIS PLACE NOW. IM GETTING TEARY EYED THINKING OF IT.JEANS: OK by far, even with tshirtORDER: at counter

Make reservation. Reserve not only seat but also Beggar Chicken, Peking Duct. Bring your own wine. Expect waiting 15,20 minutes, even with reservation. Expect noisy, homey atmosphere.  Expect crowds and parking on bingo area.

I'm in love. I called the day before to make a reservation and reserve a duck. Post Christmas and pre NYE, the place was packed with big parties. Our reservation was for 7:30, but it took roughly 20 minutes to be seated. I wasn't mad though. It was chaotically busy, and the manager/owner (?) did his best to accommodate us after I inquired how much longer the wait would be. Thank you! Our server was very sweet even though she was busy. Our appetizers came out quickly. The hot and sour soup is delicious and truly sour. The duck was carved table side and we got the fluffy white buns although they do have the flat pancakes too. It was the best duck I've had since a trip to China ten years ago. I didn't know we had such good duck in Texas! It beats any Chinatown duck in San Francisco. I can't wait to come back. I literally think about this duck sometimes and how much I want one again. Random note: you can choose a duck soup or stir fry for the rest of your duck. I opted for half and half and they were both DELICIOUS. For 30 something dollars you get two courses for two people which is four meals. Incredibly worth it. I am genuinely curious as to whether they use your specific duck or just have a bunch of random ducks from everybody else and portion it out without separating your duck from the others. Not that it matters but I am just curious.

Mr. Wok seems like a very Americanized Chinese place.They menu seems to include Chinese, Japanese & Thai dishes and the staff seemed so American, that I'm not even sure if they speak Chinese.  As a result, the clientele was all American.Bring your own wine.Ordered:-Crispy Tofu-Appetizer Sampler-Pad Thai-Eggplant-Bok Choy & Mushrooms-Peking Duck (Stir fried second)Everything except for the Peking duck was boring & uninteresting.The Peking duck, however, was great.  Carved tableside, skin separated from meat, traditional pancakes instead of steamed buns & the carcass served in a second course.  The meat wasn't greasy, the skin was crispy,  & the carcass was delicious.__________________________Conclusion:(The Beggar's Chicken looked good, but required ordering 2 days in advance)The Peking Duck is fantastic.  The rest is skippable.

Eating here without eating Peking duck is like going to chic fil a without eating chicken. The beggars chicken is another novel thing that is worth trying at least once.However I lack the same enthusiasm for the rest of the menu. The service is a bit slow at times and the place is packed during peak hours. But I'm not complaining cause I would imagine the cost of food would go up tremendously if they tried to address these problems.Jack is the most mild mannered and friendliest person you'd ever meet for having 18" arms. Overall this is one of the must try places if you are trying to get authentic chinese food in plano.

Beijing duck is good! But remember reserve that one or two days ago.Duck with the pancake which is right exactly the same way that we had in Taiwan. However, the sauce is a little bit sour.  In my memory, the sauce should be sweet and salty, but not sour.Fried water Spinach is just exactly good as in Taiwan.Fried egg plants with pork is also great!The fried fish looks amazing but I think it's too greasy for me.  My friends finished that big fish, and they said it was good!

Best Chinese food in Plano!!I'm not a big Chinese food person but I landed here last week since I couldn't find a table at a big name Asian restaurant. We were a party of eight. We ordered a lot of dishes including the Peking duck (two courses), fried rice, whole snapper, noodles, beef etc. I ll admit the summer noodles weren't the best but everything else more than exceeded my expectations. Service is awesome and servers are polite too. A must try for Chinese food lovers.

Food was very good. Like most people have already stated, even with reservation, expect an additional 15 to 30 minutes wait because this place stays packed. Also reserve peking ducks and beggars chicken if this is want you are wanting to try. Also of equal importance is BYOB. Owner is also very friendly which is a plus.
- Great lunch or dinner spot - Better then typical chinese food spots. Higher quality

I see that one of my friends who I came to Mr. Wok with has already written a stellar review (Victoria W., I'm calling you out), so let me try to top her. My only reliable comparison of Peking Duck is to Houston's choices of amazing Chinese food. The neat thing about this place is you can order the peking duck with the fluffy buns or the tortilla wraps. For Mr. Wok, I prefer the buns. Everything else was delicious and it was also new to me that they shave the duck in front of you. Please refer to Victoria W.'s review should you wish to compare it to actual Chinese food in China... Ok, where was I? Oh yeah, the service was fast and great! We ordered one peking duck and several side dishes. Unfortunately I can't recall how much it came out to be but splitting tons of food five ways was extremely affordable. Perhaps I was too excited about playing Bingo next door afterwards. I apologize. It's a bit stuffy in there but worth it! Make sure to make reservations ahead of time and specify that you're reserving a duck (or two, or three).

This place might be our best find yet. It was packed on a Saturday night and we had to wait almost an hour - but it was worth it. We enjoyed the sampler tray to start (the puffed shrimp and crab ragoons were a mazing.)We then shared the combination fried rice, sizzling sea food skillet and chicken with green beans. Everything was fresh and perfectly cooked - not greasy or over fried. We also went home with lots of leftovers. We want to go back and try the pecking duck. And everything else.
Best duck in Texas!!All the foods are pretty customizable to fit your likings as wellsuper awesome

My friends and I were looking for a place to eat Peking duck in Dallas Texas and Mr.Wok is the place! The duck was amazing and it's just like how they offer it in China. They come to your table, shave the duck and you get to choose to eat the carcass in a soup dish or stir fry (choose the soup!) Make sure that you call ahead if you want to try the duck. You need to make reservations 24 hours in advance to reserve a duck, which is also a plus because it gets pretty packed! Another bonus to Mr. Wok is that it is BYOB!Other than that, it is a pretty much Americanized Chinese restaurant. The positive side is that there is good service. The negative is that the other dishes are typical of any other Americanized Chinese restaurant. Nonetheless, I would definitely go back. I want to try the Beggar's Chicken!

Small cozy restaurant looks like it might've been an old pizza hut. The place is always packed though. The food keeps you coming back! Get the peking duck (I think you might have to call ahead for it). It's great food and a show in one. The duck is carved in front of your face and is served with the traditional buns or tortilla. I recommend trying the tortilla out, it's definitely better than using the bun!The mango shrimp is also another one of my favorites. YUM!

Everything we had was awesome; even the server.  We started with potstickers and stir fried edamame.  So good we ordered more.  Then shrimp pai tai, mango shrimp, tangy crispy beef and crispy sizzling rice soup.  When your picky 8 year old says it's the best place ever, you know it must be good.

I remembered to order the duck 24 hours in advance and we got there at 5:30 so it wasn't crowded until we were leaving. I hope I don't get thrown out of Yelp for this but I wasn't wild about the duck. Even the thin slices were really chewy. I thought it would be really tender. But the stir fry they make with the bones was amazing - really intense flavor and texture. The owner came by the table (what a sweetheart!) and told us it's made with mustard greens. I've never had anything like it. We had the soup when we got home and it was still steaming hot. The broth had a good duck flavor and the veg was good but the bones were distracting. I'd have strained them out first. It was a big duck. Even with  two big eaters we took home enough for another meal for two. Big duck. The lo mein, veg and beef egg rolls and egg drop soup were good and the stir fry was a spectacular course. The service was great so I'm going four stars but the duck by itself would have only been three.

Our first dinner in Plano. Wow, this place is really popular! We came in around 8:30pm and its all full. We had to wait for about 30 min for a table, but the Peking duck is well worth the wait! I like Peking duck a lot but I can't eat much because of the fatty and oily skin, however here it's not really fat and grease, I really enjoyed it. One suggestion if I may, the wrap/bread/whatever u call it coming with duck is too big and too thick... Smaller size and thinner texture will further enhance the taste I think.

I was hesitant to try this place out because I was never a fan of duck, but I was told that I HAD to try Peking duck since I haven't had it..... and ever since I was introduced to this place a few months ago, when someone suggests we eat Peking Duck, I'm automatically down. We always call ahead to reserve a duck or to make sure its still available. They bring the duck to your table and cut it in front of you, so if you get a little quesy seeing stuff like that, you've been warned! After they cut it, they given you the option of having stir fry or soup with the remaining duck/meat, and we always get the stir fry. Everything is perfect and I've never had a bad experience eating Peking Duck here at Mr. Wok. From the Buns to the sauce to the stir fry, everything is just so good! I've tried a few other dishes here but the Peking duck is by far my favorite.

Came here on a Tuesday night and this cozy place was packed! They managed to squeeze us in.  We tried the peking duck, fried snapper, calamari, eggplant,  green beans,  ma po tofu and edamame, and everything was delicious.  The duck was flavorful and with crispy skin.  They serve the carcass separately air fried and in soup for 2 additional entrees that were also very good.  The highlights of the meal second to the duck were the eggplant and calamari.  This place is also incredibly well priced.  My only regret is not trying more.   I will be back for more delicious Chinese food!
I have been trying Peking duck in many places. I can say Mr. Wok has the best Peking Ducking in Dallas area.

Reservation , we were right on time . We were told they were behind 10 minutes. this was no problem.  45 minutes after we watched everyone that walked in get seated before us.  We kept asking if we were going to be seated next that we had a reservation and had pre-ordered a duck, envisioned the poor duck in the back dry and cold, we asked some people in line if they had reservations--no.  All we could figure is that there was some race discrimination going on--what else could it be?  We were well dressed and polite so...We won't be back  and we will tell Everyone at our very large companies not to try Mr. Wok after all, there are s00000 many good restaurants of this type in the area!

Love the Peking duck here. Definitely one of the best ones in the area! Since it's a two course Peking duck, get the stir fried for the second part it's amazing. The way they cook it is very flavorful. TIP Make a reservation ahead of time so you don't have to wait and to reserve your duck as well.I also recommended the fired red snapper - it was delicious.

This is a two in one type of Chinese restaurant. It's so rare to find an Asian restaurant that specialize in both traditional and Americanized dishes. They have stuff like Peking duck for family style sharing on one hand and dishes like sesame chicken on the other. Great lunch specials and daily specials. Can't say anything bad about Mr.Wok...the only thing left to add is that they also have good service.

Mr. Wok is a small cozy restaurant that was pretty crowded for dinner.  Good thing we had reservations since our party was pretty big (11 people and 2 high  chairs).  We were seated immediately upon arrival.  Sitting elbow-to-elbow added to the family-style experience.  All of the servers were friendly and attentive, ensuring our drinks were always refilled throughout dinner and accommodating our requests.The food was excellent!  The starters we tried included the wok-seared edamame (unique flavor and texture for edamame), salt and pepper calamari, cool lettuce wraps, and the crispy tofu (very crispy texure).  Entrees included: mango shrimp (least favorite dish of the menu due to the heavy rich sauce and sseroggy battered shrimp), fried green beans, beef with scallions, whole steamed fish (flavorful and moist), yaki soba noodles, Beggar's chicken, and Peking duck.  The duck was crispy and juicy.  The duck was cut table side and we were left to assemble the pancake wraps with fresh scallions and hoisin sauce. The server even let my 6 year old nephew try to break open the bread surrounding the Beggar's chicken dish, which was very entertaining.The table behind us was celebrating a couple's 50th wedding anniversary with family.  This place is great for family reunions and celebrations, and for sharing an intimate, delicious meal with loved ones.
This is an updated review, following a thorough response from the business owner.  I'm just going to say that this place is not my favorite.  "Your mileage may vary."

Great food. Great people. Make sure you have reservations! And BYOB. You definitely don't come here for the ambience, and the restaurant is a little small, but if you're looking for awesome authentic Asian cuisine, you must come here. I recommend the Peking duck, but make sure you let them know when you book your reservation or they may not have one for you.

All I can say is that it's worth a trip to Plano to visit this place.  It is not the best Chinese food ever, but for the price, it is absolutely phenomenal.  Mr. Wok is located in an old Pizza Hut location, and brings all of the goodness of that low overhead to it's prices.  Because of the small size though, the wait can be a little long at peak times.  Consistently rated in the "top restaurants in Dallas" lists, it's really a hidden gem.  They have an incredibly wide selection on their menu -- on the last trip, I had the hot and sour soup (great), an egg roll, and the twice cooked pork (also really good!).  Other folks at the table had crunchy beef (yum), spicy shrimp, and spicy basil noodles.  They were all pleased, and lots of sharing occurred.  The best part: we fed a table of six, with lots of appetizers, for $85.  This is the genius of Mr. Wok -- great food and outstanding value.  Awesome!

I first came here 2 years ago to try their ramen. I wasn't a fan. A couple of days ago, my friend suggested we eat here for their peking duck. We called the day before to make a reservation for a table and the duck. It came with both traditional buns and thin "pancakes," which were essentially tortillas that you could get at the store. They carve the duck right at your table side and ask if you would like a stir-fry or soup made with the bones. We picked stir-fry - it was good but I wished they just carved all of it instead of making it into a stir-fry. The actual peking duck was delicious though. The skin was very crispy! It's not the best I've had but I was definitely satisfied. On the other hand, my table ordered 4 more dishes and they weren't that good. Portions were also small.

If you have a hankering for Peking duck, Mr Wok is the place to be. I have to say, Mr. Wok's duck does live up to the lean all natural grade name. At Mr Wok, you will NOT find fat in between the skin and meat of the duck. You will be able to chew on the crispy duck skin without the gelatinous fat. *YUMS* My only issue with the whole Peking duck course is that the steam buns were not the best i've had. It did not seem fluffy, fresh and spongy. The skin wrap on the other hand was a much bigger disappointment. Definitely go for the steam buns here if you have to pick the lesser of two evils. Overall, a great place to have Peking duck at an AFFORDABLE price. I will be back to try the beggar's chicken. Just wished the steam buns were perfected a little more!

Without a doubt, the only place I will go to for Peking Duck. Mr. Wok is a tiny restaurant with very limited parking and an average Chinese menu but their Peking Duck is literally perfection. The duck is so delicious that you have to reserve your duck a day prior at least to ensure you'll have one. I love how they bring the duck to your table and cut it in front of you and that they take the bones to make a soup or stir fry. The duck wrapped within the buns they provide is so good and it's nice that they offer additional buns at no cost. It is definitely the leanest duck I've had but at the same time, not dry. We also got the eggplant with pork which was good. The Mango Shrimp is tasty but very small portion for the price. The Sampler Starter is something fun to order and allows you to try quite a few things but out of the six appetizers on the sampler, I probably only found one or two to my liking. I highly recommend this restaurant for the Peking Duck.

So it turns out that my current roomie grew up next door to the owner of this fine establishment.  She told me that they are the best Chinese restaurant in the DFW area.  I was rather skeptical since I'm such a snob so of course I needed to try it out myself.  Thankfully I was in town for a work trip and our hotel was a mere 10 minutes away. We arrived rather early [they were still setting up the dining room!], and we had our choice of tables.  We told them that we heard the Peking Duck was amazing but knew we had to order it a day ahead.  Luckily they make a couple extra and we were able to get one since we were the first people to arrive.  Lucky us!We ordered some calamari and Cho Cho for an appetizer.  What a great start to the meal.  If it was an indicator for how excellent the meal was, I knew we were in for a treat.When the duck was ready, the owner stopped by our table to carve it for us and told us the story about why their duck is superior to others.  Woah!  He was right!  The meat was so dang tender and the skin was perfectly crispy.  How'd they do it?!  Magic I tell you!  Absolute sorcery!!!For the second course of the duck we had it as a stir-fry.  That was amazing as well.  So many flavors!This is definitely one yummy quacker!!!Next time I am in town I know I will be coming back here!!!! Thanks Jack!!!  :)

Wowzers! This place is so authentic! The beef fried rice isn't loaded with soy or over-fried, it is cooked to perfection! The beef & broccoli is so juicy. The owner greets you upon entering & is so friendly! I have read numerous reviews on their Peking duck, so we asked the owner about the ordering process & he said they will be able to have it ready with a 24hr advance notice, so that will be next on the menu. This place has won so many recognitions! There are pics of Dallas Cowboys & Stars players dining here. And it is 5 mins from my new place so that's a score! Love local!!! I'll update my review after trying the duck...to be continued...

Oh Mr. Wok, I love you. You keep me hangin' on. In addition to the Peking duck being the star of the show, this place also makes other great dishes. Definitely get their red snapper and the green beans in garlic sauce. Do make a reservation because that's the only way you will avoid waiting in the cramped foyer eyeing everyone else, enduring a 1 hour wait!

PEKING DUCK = BOMB! although it requires an extra step of having to pre-order it, just doooo it. You will be glad that you did! I usually come here with a fairly big group so we end up ordering family style.  A lot of the dishes that i've had don't really stand out to me.  I think a lot of people, like myself come here for the Peking duck.  The beggar's chicken is also something cool on their menu but I think it's just neat in terms of presentation but not sure if it's worth it for the taste.  The chicken soup (small size) is HUMONGOUS and will feed a lot of people despite the the recommended portion size of 8-10.  There's supposed to be a lot of good healthy stuff in the soup but I am just not a fan.  It's super bland to me; perhaps it's because i specifically told them to leave out the msg. I want to praise their staff!  They are very friendly and constantly checks up on you! Amazing customer service!  I know asian restaurants have a rep for poor customer service but not here!

Mr.Wok has been around since my middle school and high school days and they have THE BEST peking duck. It's always on point and Jack, the owner usually does a cool job carving it in front of you and then they make a delicious soup out of the bones. My other favorite dish there is the mango shrimp! It's so good and different from your typical dishes at Chinese restaurants. Also I never like lettuce wraps at other restaurants but theirs are fresh and full of meat. Definitely try this place out if you like Chinese food! The owners are so friendly and the food is great!

Love the food here! Words cannot describe how awesome this place is! This place is tucked away in East Plano, where you often may forget its existence! Gather your friends and family, come out here and enjoy a traditional Chinese dinner together. They're always busy, even at 9pm! It's crazy. You may have to call ahead to reserve your Peking Duck. That's a dish that often is "sold out!"

We went based primarily on the great Yelp reviews.  All in all, it was a great experience.  It was very busy on a Thursday night, but we were seated right away.  Our server was new, but he did a great job and knew a lot about the menu.  There were 3 of us.  One had the mango shrimp.  He said the shrimp were really good, but the mango was just a bit green.  I had a spicy beef dish (forgot the name), and it was great - very fresh tasting with green beans.  Our friend had the green bean dish which she said was outstanding.  We also had two appetizers - crispy fried tofu and potstickers.  Definitely.After we finished eating, the manager (or owner) came by and asked how everything was and thanked us for coming.  We had mentioned to the server when ordering that it was our first time there, and he must have shared that with the manager.  Really nice touch. We will definitely go back.  Both the server and manager mentioned the Peking Duck and suggested ordering in advance.  Will definitely be giving that a try. If you want great food and good service, this is a must.  It's not much for ambiance, but quite frankly, it was a non-issue.  I reserve my 5th star for after I've tried the Peking DuckOh...they do take reservations, and based on the Thursday night crowd, I'll definitely make a reservation next time (even though we didn't have to wait to be seated).

The Peking duck is so good. It's a 3 course meal with an excellent presentation. Also, have to note the calamari, pan seared edamame, eggplant and whole tilapia in black bean sauce were very good. Make a reservation or plan to wait a good while.

I never thought I would be writing a review of a place called Mr. Wok that's located in an old Pizza Hut building in suburban Dallas, but here I am.  And while I'm not Asian I have the say the food on multiple visits has been consistently good - and most of the clientele is Asian.  Quite frankly it's a bit of a strange menu of different flavors including edamame, lettuce wraps, egg rolls, Chinese-American dishes, and even Pad Thai.  It seems to be mostly Chinese food for American tastes but there's a little something here for everybody and the food is consistently well made with good flavor.  As one of my colleagues described it, Mr. Wok is just what you expect from Chinese food - that's about as good as you're gonna get in North Texas.

The food:Peking duck is amazing crispy and delicious when wrapped up. It's a good idea to reserve one before heading over, otherwise they may run out. They also make the rest of the duck into a soup or fried rice. Mango shrimp was good. Fresh mangos, wish there were more pieces of shrimp in it, howeverJapanese eggplant was tender and flavorfulFried tofu app was fried to perfectionOverall, everything I tried was good to amazingThe service:Prompt, friendly, helpful. Environment:Nothing to rave about. It's like a traditional Chinese restaurant. But I'd come back for the food and service.

3.5 stars.I was so afraid that when I came to Plano that I would not find a decent Chinese restaurant. And I was kinda right and kinda wrong.I came here with a friend that was a strict vegetarian (no eggs/meat), and was very pleased that they are so accommodating here: essentially substituting any meat for no meat or tofu at your request on virtually any dish.  He ordered the Chow Fun with no meat and was more than pleased with it. It didn't look oily either like some Chow Funs can be.We started with these excellent Fried Crispy Tofu squares, soft tofu squares that were served on a bed of shredded lettuce and black sesame seeds and a tasty peanut sauce. Perfectly crisp and hot. Really good starter.I had the Mango prawns (one of the house specialties) and it was beautifully presented in a thin shelled fried bowl over crispy rice noodles. The only problem was that the fresh, sweet mango was so cold, that it actually cooled down the large prawns and the dish was oddly cool/cold. After having so many honey-walnut prawns that did not have this problem, it was unexpected to have this one turn out that way. That said, the mango was generous and very sweet, and the  prawns were perfectly done.The service was very friendly as well and there were lots of pictures of the dishes on display for the non-asians in all of us. They even had two versions of the menu (English+Chinese, and English only)The only nit pick was that I asked for a side of rice that was supposed to be fried rice, and the only thing fried about it was the color. It looked like they took steamed rice, sprayed it with enough soy sauce to make it light brown and then threw two or three peas and carrots in it to add color. It was not very good and I did not finish even this small bowl.I can't say that this place was very authentic but then I was not expecting it to be. I'd need to return to sample more of their dishes to be sure, but for now I'm rounding up to 4 stars.

Absolutely great, I know you are reading my review but this is one out of many restaurant I would recommended to you HERE IS the reason whyFRIENDLY STAFFS: I'm telling you, they are so nice, not only they are taking care of you, they also make you feel like you are having a family meal.FOOD: I'm not saying they are the best I ever had but they are trying their best to provide you the best meal in the restaurant. (p/s: Manager will listen to what you have to say about your experience at his restaurant- share your thought y'all)Love this place:)

This place is AMAZING! My husband and I will drive 30-40 minutes to fulfill our craving for this place. Our favorite is the peking duck and the cool wraps. You have at least 2 days worth of take home food too. Jack is super friendly and welcoming! He pretty much knows all of his customers very well. The staff is always friendly and ready to serve.  We will continue to keep coming here for many years to come. -Kimmi and Andy
The duck is great, so is the new thin wraps that's much more authentic Beijing style.

Fantastic Chinese food.  I tried the Rangoons, egg rolls, beef with broccoli and Kung pao chicken.  Excellent in taste.....Kung pao chicken could have been hotter but most Americans are weenies and can't handle it.

Located on the east side of Plano in an unassuming standalone hole in the wall that looks like it used to be a Taco Bell or fried chicken joint.  Mr. Wok is a no frills kinda place, but plenty of culinary thrills.  The best Peking duck in the DFW area.  Love the table side finish of the duck, not too fatty and oh so good.  Order the buns to go with.  You also get the choice of soup or stirfry as a secondary dish from the duck bones.  I love the stirfry and gnawing on tasty bones, definitely the old school Asian girl in me.  And to top it off, it's BYOB!  Get out there.  It's good eats!!

It seems that everyone has heard of the Mr. Wok duck. It's their signature dish, served as a 3 course meal, but only if you get there in time! The duck must have renowned popularity because it was 86'd by dinner, even on a random mid-week night. But the fried tofu and ramen were still good substitutes! its BYOB, which is good or bad, depending on your preference. In case you arrive unprepared, the waitress noted that the gas station around the corner has a decent alcohol selection. IMHO, the decor could using some sprucing up. But the service was top notch!

Mr. Wok- I wanted to vomit after I left, but in a good way.This place is interesting. The building used to be a Pizza Hut and it still has remnants from its past which is amusing. I'm pretty sure the booths have been there since 1985, still very comfy. I would recommend reservations, this place isn't huge and gets very crowded very quickly on a weekend.We had the peking duck. I think some reviews said the duck had no flavor or was bland. I think where they are coming from is that the ducks they used (sourced from Long Island) are very lean. Without that fat, you get a different taste to the meat and even to the skin.  I prefer the fattier ducks since it makes the meat more moist and flavorful, but for a lean duck, this was very good. Definitely opt to pay a little extra for the steam buns for the duck; who the hell eats this stuff with tortillas? Weirdos. They also carve the duck for you which is nice- allows for lazy eating.We also had the mango shrimp, which was a nice switch, something refreshing after eating all the duck.  The milk sauce that is mixed with the mangoes might have been a bit much, made it a little too sweet. I would have preferred it without the sauce, but to each their own. And I still ate the whole thing up, so, whatever.Oh, I also ate all the crispy lo mein noodle things that came with my friend's soup at the beginning. Those were pretty good too, but I think it prevented me from eating a 5th duck bun.All in all, a fun experience with some tasty food. Not that expensive either, so that's always a plus. I think next time I'll have to try the beggar's chicken so I can bash the crap out of the loaf that the chicken is baked in.

Love this place and have been going there for years now.  My fave dishes are The calamariThe Chicken chahung& the seared edemameNo matter what I am in the mood for I order those 3 items. Yum. O and call ahead if you want the duck. it's also really good.

I absolutely love this place. I first came here like 10 years ago, and the food has consistently been excellent since day one.My current favorite is the spicy parmesan prawns, they are spicy and delicious and just oh so good, and the great thing is they don't skimp on the portion.

Came here for lunch, ordered Hunan chicken, nice sauce tons of veggies, we'll cooked, but not overdone, also had egg drop soup,  a little fancier than the normal fast food places, my only complaint is where's the chicken? My plate had micro pieces of chicken. But it's very tasty, rice was nice and abundant,  a little but not overly sticky

I have picked up take out from Mr. Wok several times and loved it.  Last night, my fiancee' and I went to dine in and liked it just as much. We started off with soup and an order of steamed dumplings.  The wonton soup is excellent and served in a cup size portion- perfect as a starter.  The steamed dumplings are filled with pork and cabbage and I love the sauce that comes with them. My fiancee' had the Four Treasures- Chicken, Shrimp, beef and pork in a garlic sauce served with noodles and really liked it.  I had the Cashew Chicken with fried rice.  The Cashew Chicken was the best I have had in a long time.  Compared to other Chinese places in the area- Mr. Wok is a bargain.  The prices are great and the restaurant is BYOB.  Will definitely go back soon with my family.

This was our first time to try this place, but it won't be the last. Every item we ordered was awesome. The wok seared noodles were tasty. The shrimp fried rice was loaded with shrimp. Lastly, the Szechuan pork was just the right spicy and tasty at the same time.  We ordered both the egg drop and hot & sour soup. While the egg drop was excellent, the h&s needed a bit more cabbage and carrots to the broth. The place was packed an the service was still excellent.

Please do not be fooled by the outside of the building, which appears to be a former Pizza Hut.  Mr. Wok puts people that judge a book by its cover to shame!I gave this place 5-stars because there is absolutely no other place in Big D that serves Peking Duck of this quality.  If you aren't a fan of duck skin, then this obviously isn't the place for you.  If you understand and enjoy the intricacy/complexity of roasting a duck, then this is duck heaven for you...Mr. Wok actually ships its all-natural ducks in from Long Island, NY.  They specifically use very low fat ducks to maximize the crispiness of the dish.  This is essential in Peking Duck!  It also prevents one from confusing juiciness with fat content, which is crucial PD mistake in many Chinese restaurants in the area.  The Peking Duck dish comes at around $30, but the owner slices up the skin in front of you, which only adds to the restaurant experience.  Afterwards, you have a choice of second dish by stir frying the remaining duck meat/bones or making a soup noodle broth.  Don't forget to call the day before to reserve your duck, because it's difficult to get them made-to-order.I also enjoy eating the "Ton Chun" soup noodles, which translates into homestyle noodles.  The soup broth is serious business--smoky in nature, which means that there is a long brewing process involved.  The noodles also come with julienned  vegetables and sliced, tenderized pork cutlets.  For the price, this huge bowl of soup noodles is a $7 bargain!Also, be sure to try out the mango shrimp and lettuce wraps.  Neither are outstanding, but great compliments to the PD.

If you haven't been to this place, then you should try it out at least once. Be prepared though to wait in line if you haven't done any reservation. In this instance, my experience here was related to a friend who had a birthday party.We had several dishes family style, and I can vouch that every one of them was fantastic and tasted authentic. The peking duck is what the are known for and that was very good. Just to give you an idea, everywhere I have eaten Peking duck has had their very own signature.This location will bring the duck out and carve it there on the spot. The bun is fresh and so are the condiments needed. About the location though, ignore the fact that this used to be a pizzaria. Note that there isn't that many parking space, especially when its packed... and it was definitely packed that evening when I went there. Other then that, the staff was awesome and catered to our needs. I really like the place a lot and expect to show up again for Peking duck.

Best Peking Duck in Dallas! Went with my whole family and we all loved it.My Parents tried other dishes too and it all came out really good!. It's BYOB so we brought a bottle of wine. I have been trying to find a good place after I moved from San Antonio and finally found it we will be regular customers for sure!
Best Peking duck ever. Must call and reserve table in advance. They are alway booked. Super busy place.

Peking Duck was excellent!The first course, that was....the second one (we had it stir fried) was just so-soBeggar's chicken was just ok....calamari was good, though a little saltyEdamame was really goodBut service, oh service, was BAAAAD-----underline BAAAAADthe waitress never bothered to ask us what we wanted or asked how we were doing....had to flag down the waitress three separate timesOnce to order foodSecond to ask where our beggar chicken wasThird was to ask where our duck wasFrom edamame/calamari, it was perhaps 20-25 min wait for the chicken, then another 20-25 min for the duck, then another 20 min for the stir-fried duck. Totally had to stop eating while waiting for the duck and chicken to come...intervals in between. Spent 2 hours (without actually eating the stir-fried duck, once it came, we asked for it to be put in doggy bag and left) in the establishment. And we came at 6.30 pm, when the restaurant was half-empty, so I don't know why we had to wait that long for the chicken./duck to come. Had made a reservation for the chicken 2 days prior.It looks like every table ordered Peking Duck without fail. So why we had to wait that long for the stir-fried duck, we didn't know....If you must have that Peking Duck, you can come.....but if you're limited on time, I'd advise you not to come here.

I would have loved to write a review on their food but here's their policy. They only make reservations for groups of 6 or more so DON'T plan of just showing up on a Saturday night and expect to be seated if there are just 2 of you.

My family loves, loves, loves Chinese food. What do we eat at home? Chinese food. What do we eat when we go out? Chinese food. What kind of take-out food would you like? Chinese food. Would you like any other kind of ethnic food? Funnnnyy, go walk to McDonald's while mama and papa enjoy our Chinese food. :(Also- whenever my family eats at Chinese restaurants, it tends to be the same things:  some sort of soup, a meat dish (usually sweet and sour pork), a veggie dish (like a hot pot), combination fried rice, and fried flat beef noodles. Family full of adventurists willing to try new things coming to Mr. Wok, woo! (Note the sarcasm)Dad after a day of shopping: "What would you like to eat?"...Yeah, okay.~~~~~~~Anyways, Mr. Wok was recommended to him by a friend who stated that their peking duck was phenomenal and that you had to try the restaurant at least once. This restaurant never would have stumbled across my father's radar of restaurants he would like to try if not for the said friend from above. It was a pretty early dinner (around 5 PM) so there wasn't any crowd at all and we were able to be seated fairly quickly. Service was great! We asked to be moved to a different table because it was right under lots of ceiling fans and we were accommodated to a booth when the table became available. Because this was a spur of the moment eating, we had no reservation for Peking duck or beggar's chicken, so poo...no duck for us. :( Actually...now looking at what we ordered, we actually did venture...kind of away from what we usually do...The food was "eh."First the fried rice and the yakisoba noodles came out and the presentation of the food was nicer than what I was expecting...except...IS THAT HAM IN MY FRIED RICE and you garnished it with pickled ginger?? Fine..fine. The yakisoba noodles were way too sweet and had to be eaten with white rice later on in the dish to help.Sweet and sour pork was plated beautifully too...except that I felt like I was being lied to. Sweet and sour pork. What do I expect in that dish? Sweet and sour pork. This dish had like..12 pieces (I'm being generous with this number) placed diagonally in a row  in a square plate with mounds of mushrooms, onions, and carrots on each side.What?! No Mr. Wok! No! Give me my meat! Steamed tilapia with a black bean sauce. Once again, plated beautifully. but why is there pork in this sauce? Too sweet, but the tilapia was very nicely steamed and was good. The sauce was a different matter. With the expectation of every dish being plated beautifully, they then brought out our fried duck. This dish was literally "fried duck" cut into pieces and pushed onto a plate and served to us. No garnish, no greenery under the fried duck to help with this shade of brown. Duck wasn't particularly flavorful and was on the dry side but I guess that's why they had the condiments on the side to dip it in. When comparing the prices of this Asian diner to other Chinese places, it is considered to be a bit higher (Probably paid ~$15 per person compared to the usual $8-9) for food that isn't considered worth it. Sure, it's still considered to be reasonable and cheap when compared to restaurant prices in general, but in the world of Asian restaurants, I do believe it is on the pricier side of average. Was the food worth the price? No.Was the service great? Yes! Was I wowed? NoWill I be back? Don't count on it unless it is to try out the infamous Peking duck. If 2 1/2 stars was possible, this would have been the rating I would have given. So my advice is to come here for the Peking duck but go elsewhere if you're craving more authentic Asian cuisine from other restaurants.

We just moved here, and we were so excited to find a wonderful Chinese restaurant so quickly! The Peking Duck is simply delicious. Not at all greasy or boney. The Moo Shoo is also fantastic. Service is always wonderful: prompt & friendly without hovering. Prices are great, too. They don't serve alcohol, so bring your own. Atmosphere is very casual, and the restaurant isn't that large -- so make reservations or be prepared to wait a bit. But it's definitely worth it!

The Peking Duck with all the trimmings is curved table side by Jack the owner. The Chow fun noodles has that smoky taste. Quite a good place for a nice dinner at a  very reasonable price in a friendly atmosphere.. Service was quite alright  , though very busy on a Tuesday  at 6;00 . Weekends might be too crowded. Next time we'll try the Beggars  Chicken. I'm happy to find a new place  for food and value. We'llbe repeat customers for sure.

Quack Quack Quack.One of the best things I've eaten in Dallas in a while......for $32, you get a Peking Duck served three ways- slow roasted and sliced, served with moo shoo pancakes, then stir fried with onions and some sort of greens, and then served in a soup.  Heavenly - the rest of the menu includes a stuffed chicken cooked 24 hours (Beggar's), a whole cooked fish, and a whole lotta other goodness.  Can't wait to come back.

I'm not sure about the food. It wasn't bad just bland. The sweet and sour chicken was tasteless and the sauce wasn't sweet nor sour, it kind of had a chlorine taste to it, city water maybe? The beef and broccoli was excellent along with the chow mien. The portions were satisfactory as well. I might give it another shot but will try else where before I do.

The one thing you need to know about this place is the Peking Duck.  You can't get this dish at many establishments in the area, and the fact that they actually know how to make Mr. Wok pretty awesome.  You will need to make sure you call in your order many hours before hand.  I would suggest you place your order in the morning because they need time to perfect this dish.  Their other stuff is decent, but there's honestly nothing special with their dishes compared to other restaurants.The decor is a little weird and you really do feel like you're in an Asian establishment as it's not exactly the cleanest place.  No worries as the aroma of your feast will overpower any strange scent you smell on your way in.  I will definitely be back soon!
Best Chinese restaurant around my house. Love the food and great service it's always crowded so I always have to do take out!
Soooo good! The place is a little outdated, but the food is among the best I've ever had. Service was excellent, price was very affordable. I highly recommend it.

Just spent 30 minutes waiting to be seated in a 1/2 full house...only to be told there was no seat available for an hour. What a waste. Terrible service. Was going here for a celebration dinner but will never be back.

There aren't many places for Peking duck in the DFW area. This place, not only serves duck, but it is excellent. They serve it in two dishes-the second either being a stir fry or a traditional soup. The service is also dig-in fun. It is bring your own wine, and it is recommended to call ahead for your duck, but they usually have extras. Jack and Alison were great fun to visit. We will be back!

Hooooly DUCK. Didn't know ducks had that much protein...other places have always given me 80% fat and 20% meat. Mr. Wok proved me wrong. Following reviews, I ordered ahead and thank goodness I did, otherwise they would have run out. The waiter brought out the duck roasted to perfection and cut it in front of us. He plated the skin and meat and took the rest of the duck back to have it sautéed. (You can either have it sautéed or in a soup) this also was amazing. All in all, the pecking duck was ducking amazing, our waiter was helpful and friendly, the portion was perfect for two, and the duck was again...ducking delicious. I would suggest going on a weekday when it's less crowded. Again, order ahead! Will return to try the beggars chicken. Thanks Mr. Wok for the good duck experience. 5 stars and a happy dance from me!

I came here with a large group. We knew it would probably be busy so we made a reservation ahead of time. We got there early and they said we couldn't be seated until the time our reservation, which is fine. But when it's time for our reservation we go ask to see if a table is a ready and they said "oh, we actually just put a group in the table we were going to seat you at. It'll be about 20 more minutes." What! They let us order ahead of time before we sat so we got our food faster which is nice. But they messed up my order bad tried to say it was what it said on the menu, but they must have been looking at a different menu than me. The food was good but I the service was sub par.

Don't get fooled by the physical appearance of this place.  Although it looks like an old Pizza Hut, the food alone will make you forget of the lack of decor.  I have dined here for many occasions last year and this year, and have not been disappointed by the food nor service.  It's BYOB here, they will provide you with ice and storage.  Food:  for the Peking duck, you must order this at least 1-2 days in advance.  The duck is crispy, and carved tableside.  For the duck meat, you have 2 options of getting tortillas or steamed buns to eat with.  For the left over duck bones that have alittle bit of meat still in tact on the bone, you also have 2 options eating that as well.  The server will carve the duck meat off of the bones, and ask you if you want to use the bones to make a duck soup or saute the bones.  Both options are good, if you go here enough times you should try both.  Mango shrimp:  this dish is slightly sweet from the fresh mangos that it is served with.  The shrimp is lightly battered, then fried and tossed in a mayonnaise type sauce, and served in a empty mango skin and a bed of fried glass noodles.  It's a spin off of the walnut shrimp at most chinese places.  Begger's chicken:  the chicken is marinated, wrapped in foil and then wrapped with dough that covers the entire chicken.  The chicken is then baked and brought out to your table.  You then get to pound on the harden dough to open up the chicken inside.  This dish definitely add entertainment value to your dinner, but takes a lot of work.

Stopped here based on a recommendation from a coworker, and we weren't disappointed. Though the lo mein was made from spaghetti noodles (a pet peeve of mine), it was still tasty, as was my mom's almond chicken. Our crab rangoon appetizer looked a little well done, but they were ok none the less. Staff was nice, and the prices fair. We will be going back.

my dad and i were super excited to try this place, given their ad in the chinese newspaper and how they were listed in dallas' top 100 restaurants (or something of that sort). after seeing the menu once we arrived, i was kindof skeptical because i've learned that generally, if your establishment cooks all of the various asian cuisines, then how good is the food? i decided to give mr. wok the benefit of the doubt, and my dad and i ended up ordering the two-course duck, marinated jellyfish, and ma po tofu. when the duck arrived, the waiters presented a whole duck and sliced the skin and meat in front of us, which made it look and smell all the more delicious. however, it was a huge, tasteless disappointment, especially at the price we paid and how popular mr. wok seemed, well, everywhere. the rest of the dishes were just the same: very, very mediocre. the ma po tofu was nowhere near spicy, and the marinated jellyfish was way too sweet. however, the point in our dinner when i decided mr. wok was just a no-go was when a fly landed on our jellyfish. disgusting, not to mention that it kept buzzing around our booth, too. when we pointed it out to the waiters, they didn't seem to really care that, well, there was a fly in their restaurant that would normally question their hygiene/health standards. the only part i actually enjoyed from the meal was the second course of the duck, the duck soup, which was very light and refreshing.overall, mr. wok was just a huge disappointment. the food was tolerable, but honestly i wouldn't come back. duck is way overhyped for what it's worth vs. what you get, and it bothers me that the staff seems so lax about flies in the restaurant.

Mr. Wok what would I do without you?Although it's a bit of a trek from Uptown to get a meal at Mr. Wok, it's definitely always been worth it. The duck you get at Mr. Wok is the best you can get here in Dallas. It's perfectly cooked and the duck retains all it's wonderful and beautiful juices. The skin is crisped to perfection and the duck is carved expertly tableside. It comes with scallions, black bean paste, and chinese buns (no pun intended). You fill up the little warm buns with some crisp and juicy pieces of duck, put on a thin layer of black bean paste, throw some scallions on top and take a bite. The explosion of flavor and textures is ethereal. Then again, I've always liked duck so take that last comment with a grain of salt. They take the rest of the duck that's left over and will cook it for you 1 of 2 ways. 1. stir fry. 2. soup. Go for 1. It's much more flavorful and although there isn't a ton of meat left once the carving is complete, the stir fry flavor and little sinews of meat are worth the effort. As for the soup, it's bland and underwhelming.Did I ever tell you about the day I came here to Mr. Wok when they ran out of a duck? I was depressed for about a week. When I first heard they were all sold out, my heart sunk. When I saw them delivering the last of their pre sold ducks to other customers my heart shriveled up and died. Mr. Wok isn't Mr. Wok without the duck. You need the duck. The duck is a must. Let's say the duck disappeared. I woudln't come here.

Went on a Saturday evening. Arrived at 6:20. I family waiting before us. Estimated wait for table: 90 minutes.I know the place is small but their policy of only accepting reservations for parties of 6 or more or for parties who pre-order the Peking Duck is ridiculous.I also do not believe that the entire restaurant was filled for the next 90 minutes with large parties and/or Peking Duck orders.I get the feeling, if you're a regular and the owner likes you, you'll get a table even without the above restrictions.

You out there? Yes, you. The one reading this review. The one who is using Yelp because you are a rebel! You don't believe the hype your friends spew and you're skeptical of just how good something can be when clearly millions of people can be wrong (example: we live in a world where Martin Lawrence is probably plotting out the next seven "Big Momma's House" installments since he keeps getting funding for them). But I'm here to tell you that when it comes to Mr. Wok, the hype is justified. Believe it and see what all the fuss is about.My folks had gone here a couple of times already and after enough subtle hint dropping on my part that escalated into "Hey, when do I get to go there?," I got my golden ticket invite to see what it is Mr. Wok does that makes the place so captivating. It all comes together pretty quickly when you hit the parking lot - the place is small enough to be charming but busy enough to warrant a sign that reads something along the lines of "Extra parking in the Texas Bingo lot next door." Yes, that's right - it is possible to blend awesome Asian Bistro food and bingo in the same immediate area. Add in the fact that the place looks to have been built into an old Pizza Hut, and the "charm" factor just exploded off of the charts. We walked in on a Saturday night (which is important to note) around 6:00 and the first thing that hit me was the layout: small walkway with bathrooms on the side leading in, kitchen to the right beyond that, and to the left a dining room of a few tables and those old school booths that are never as comfortable as you think they are. And the place was already filling up. We got a corner booth and set up shop with a pretty extensive menu.Mr. Wok's is BYOB, so keep that in mind if you're planning on stopping by to hopefully experience a raging kegger followed by fortune cookies. We set our beers on the table and our server was over faster than day. And speaking of our server... This girl gets points for not only being quick, knowledgeable and funny, but also for being quirky and not obnoxious. Seriously, take Zooey Deschanel, but make her likable, and add the dialogue from "Juno," but make it tolerable, and you have this girl.And actually, everyone there was on their game. From food runners to drink re-fillers and a guy who managed to draw the shades at our booth without dislocating his arm out of his socket, everyone was engaging and amiable.But all this would be for nought if the food was lacking. And it is here where Mr. Wok's reputation shines. I'm not a lettuce wrap fan, which hurts my hipster cred, I'm sure, but they were polished off quickly at our table. Ditto the pork egg roll. And when it came time for the entrees, that was when I decided I would do my best to graze around the table as if I had never seen food before. I stuck with my chill garlic prawns, a dish that looks like it would be a disaster for anyone with facial hair (because it is) but no one should mind because it is that good (because it is). Finishing that off, I sampled the pad thai and was a fan, though not nearly as much of a fan as I was of the crispy beef. I considered ordering my own dish if not for the simple fact that dessert was on the horizon in the form of banana-chocolate spring rolls (please pause to wipe the drool) and a Vietnamese Iced Coffee (ah, there's my hipster cred coming back to the limelight... and good thing, too, since that coffee was great). The point is, everything was exceptional.And I would be remiss if I didn't mention some of the "other" factors at work here. Now all of this is heresy and rumor for me since I've been here once so take it in stride. The duck is -THE- dish here, and since business is booming, ordering one ahead of time is a surefire way to secure a reservation on the weekend... I believe. There are also meatballs that are not on the menu but can be prepared if given enough notice, and they knock the socks off of everyone in the building... I believe. And there's also a swimming pool on the roof where the girls from the camp across the lake relax... I'm almost 100 percent positive about this one.Bearing all that in mind, is it any wonder people continue to fill Mr. Wok's tables? It was a steady stream of patrons on our Saturday night visit and I'm pretty confident that's the norm most any other time of the week (except Sunday when no one is there... literally). Believe the hype, come for the food and make plans to do it all again.

Been coming here for lunch for years but finally got the family together for dinner and the famous Peking duck.   Came in with high expectations based on the reviews and they exceeded them.   Everything was great and leftovers the next day were just as good.    Will continue to make it in for lunch but will have to get the family together for the duck again.

My bf's dad told us about this place and their Peking duck. We parked and thought, this place could be a hit or a really big miss. But don't be fooled by the look, or the non Asian girl being the waitress. Yeah, we had our doubts. But this place is really a hidden treasure. Sure, some of their stuff may be a little Americanized, but when it came down to the real stuff, it's really GOOD. Best Peking duck in DFW. It's a family owned business. They know what they're doing.

One of my favorite restaurants in DFW! Whenever we have company in town this is our go to restaurant. The food is amazing and reasonably priced. A few of my favs are the duck, spicy beef, green bean and chicken, mango shrimp, edamame. The duck you need to call 24 hrs in advance. It's also BYOB! The owner Jack couldn't be any nicer and more dedicated to his restaurant. Try it you will not be disappointed.

I have been here maybe 3 or 4 times total, 2 of those times for my friends Bday.  The same guys Bday both times.  The reason he loves coming here for his bday each year is that Peking Duck.  They do such a sick job carving that puppy.  They bring it out whole in front of you, the skin is so crispy and thin, the meat so nice as they carve it, its a wonderful sight to see.  The only down side of this is they often run out of duck, which blows.  Who would of thought there is ever a shortage of ducks ?!  There is like 30 of them out by the lake near my house, they just quack and piss me off at night.We had a reservation for 16 people total, and we had to share 1 duck, since thats all they had left.... which is probably the worlds hardest thing to do.  It ranks up there along with tight rope walking, nut checking yourself, and riding a unicycle. I guess it was our mistake since we only called that same day and all their ducks but one were already sold.   WHO SELLS DUCKS OUT BEFORE LUNCH ? WHAT KIND OF NONSENSE IS THIS ?Anyways the mango shrimp dish was delicious, and so is the calamari dish.  I have no idea what its called, but we ordered 2 of those on our side of the table, and no regrets at all.  They are perfectly fried calamari with a nice spicy vinegar soy sauce mixture.  Tastes fantastic.  The restaurant is kind of in the middle of nowhere, by kind of I mean completely.  Its probably the last place you would expect to find a gourmet Chinese joint that specializes in Duck, which is quite expensive.  The dishes here are small but delicious.  If you ever go, PLEASE do yourself a favor and call in advance to reserve a duck.  For duck's sake, plan ahead.PS another hard thing to do is shoot yourself with a bbgun.

This is the second time I have been here. The service is excellent. We always get the duck and they always stand by the table and carve it up. We have a great time it's a great place to take your family and have fun please enjoy.  For the most important note the duck is absolutely phenomenal

For the most part, this restaurant sucks.  How did it get 3 stars then?  Well let me tell you a story on my situation.  I was talking to this girl from the U.S. nation...The "Chitty" (and by chitty, I meant shitty) - - Mapo Tofu - This is not close to the usual Mapo Tofu I am used to ordering from Szechuan restaurants.  It came in a brown gravy type sauce instead of hot chili pepper sauce.  Bleck.  Only dish we didn't finish.The "Meh...It's alright...but I'll eat it" - - Cheese Shrimp - Parmesan crusted fried shrimp.  Meh.- Mango Shrimp - Not truly my cup of tea, either.  Somehow, the flavors did not mesh well for me.- Steamed Tilapia in Black Bean Sauce - Steamed because a girl asked for it steamed.  I personally wanted it fried.  Not the best tasting tilapia I've had.  Some areas of the fish were a little rough.  Not too much flavorThe "Hey, I could get used to this" -- Twice Cooked pork.  This dish had a very interesting flavor.  Basically pork belly deep fried, then stir fried.  Recommended.The "WTF, that was incredible.
