Finally made the stop to Mr. Wok and I'm regretting that I didn't go sooner. As everyone said, you must reserve the duck or Beggar's chicken either a day or two days in advance, respectively. We went on a Saturday for lunch and it wasn't full or anything but toward the end of our meal, it started filling up. We reserved the duck earlier on the week and didn't have any trouble.In addition to the duck, we ordered dumplings and sesame chicken with fried rice. The dumplings were interesting. The outer skin was thick and I don't think it was steamed all the way because when I took a bite, it was still a flour-y white. It definitely wasn't the best dumpling I've had but I can tell it was made in house and not from a frozen bag. The sesame chicken with fried rice came a little bit after and it was super good! Very flavorful and the pieces of chicken was tender yet crispy even drenched in sauce. The fried rice that came with it was interesting. Not your typical fried rice but it was still tasty with the chicken. Finally the Peking duck came out (I think it took about 20 minutes or so since we sat down). The man who carved it out for us explained to us how it was marinated and he quickly carved the duck skin first then the meat. He placed the skin and meat on another plate and asked if we wanted the leftover duck stir fried or soup as a second course. So be warned that when you order the duck, it is a two course meal! We got the stir fry and it's basically the duck carcass so lots of bone fried in a sauce with mustard cabbage. It came out super fast and was flavorful but difficult to eat because of the bones. The Peking duck itself was delicious! The skin was crispy and the meat was moist. The sauce really helps bring the flavors to the buns so don't go easy on it! You also pick between pancakes or buns at the beginning. We picked the buns, obviously! Definitely worth the trip here at least once. The people were super nice and the experience was one that you don't to have much.

If you like Peking duck, I would advise checking out Mr. Wok!  Probably one of the best places in Dallas for this. Be sure to call ahead and reserve it a day in advance. The restaurant itself is small and tends to get packed so call ahead to make reservations to avoid a long wait. They bring the duck out and carve it table-side for you. The skin is crispy and the meat is tender and delicious. It also comes with steamed buns or pancakes, green onions, and hoisin sauce. For the second course, they give you the option to use the bones in a soup or stir fry which they will prepare and bring out to you. (5/5)This place is BYOB which is also a plus. I've always left happy and satisfied! Highly recommend!

Very delicious. The duck is roasted then fried. Very crispy skin. But after frying, it is a little bit too oily. If it is just roasted in oven could be perfect. Very good portion. One duck can make three different dishes: Beijing duck, duck bone soup, and stir fry duck bone. Only 35 dollars in total. Very good price for a delicious meal! And good service. Customer can even bring their own wine!! Recommend!

Well, they know me by name, so you can draw your own conclusions about my regular stops there. Mighty busy on Friday and Saturday nights but they still manage to whip out a To Go order for me. Amongst my favorite dishes are: Eggplant with chicken or pork, Spicy Green Beans with same. Need to try their Peking Duck and Beggars Chicken.

I was asked by my new coworkers what I wanted for lunch today. I said Chinese. Chinese was a very good choice..The General Tso's lunch was cheap, fast, and came with a hearty beef egg roll. Probably the best tasting chicken I've had in a long time. It was hot, juicy, fried to perfection, and the sauce was amazing! I might have to pick up some carry out before I head home after work, while I'm still training in this Plano area..

Mr. Wok is a cozy little unsuspecting Chinese restaurant in East Plano that is often praised for having the best Peking duck in the DFW. You have to order it 24 hours in advance. Another signature dish, the famous Beggar's chicken, requires a 48 hour notice. The Peking duck was just okay (for lack of a better word). I expected super moist, super tender, super juicy...and it was none of those things. What it was was very average. I do appreciate the fact that they don't waste the remainder of your duck and use it to make a second course. We opted for the stir-fry VS the soup. Not a bad flavor to the stir-fry but there was hardly any meat seeing as most of it went into our buns so maybe the soup would have been a better option. I also felt we didn't get enough buns but oh well. The Beggar's chicken is definitely cool in terms of presentation. It's one of those dishes that you order once just to say you tried it - not something I would get again. It's a fun dish to get with a group so that someone can hammer on the bread that encases the dish before your server actually cuts it open for you revealing a whole chicken wrapped in leaves. I am slightly confused seeing as the menu said it was a whole chicken stuffed with sticky rice amongst many other things mixed into it. When the bread was cut open, I only saw chicken. We mixed it around some and couldn't find any sticky rice. The overall flavor was a little underwhelming. Pretty unmemorable. Overall, I found Mr. Wok to be overhyped. The dish that everyone raves about is nothing spectacular. While this wasn't my first time having Peking duck, I wouldn't proclaim myself as a Peking duck connoisseur. The service was great though.

Came here for dinner on a Tuesday night with the family.Pros:Surprisingly decent prices.  I was expecting higher but was pleasantly surprised.Good portions - plates were fairly big and we definitely had enough foodTaste was on point.  I felt like most everything was what it should be or better except one dish the twice cooked pork could have been better.  The pork had bones and was super dry.The steamed rice was well cooked, and I'm glad it was free.Cons:  The service was a little lackluster.  The waiter could have been a little nicer and showed some more initiative.Overall I would come back.  Food tasted pretty good and good portions.

This place probably has the best Peking Duck in Dallas.  It is two courses. The first course is the traditional skin and meat with the steam buns, hoisin and scallions. The second course can either be the duck soup or stir fried duck bones. Must reserve this a day in advance.  I assure you that you will not be disappointed.  They also have the traditional Chinese dishes, which are great depending on what you like, but again, do not come here unless you order the duck.

Always a good meal here, although it can get cramped.  Therefore, always try to make reservations for dinner or even lunch.  And if you want Peking duck during the weekdays, you have to call ahead and reserve the duck because they make only so many. Peking duck here is a must and I would say it's one of the best in town as it's not greasy and really crispy.  You can select between a pancake or bun. We prefer to eat our  Peking duck with the buns. Then you can select between a crispy stir fry or soup for the remaining duck meat and bones.  Go with the stir fry as it's a very flavorful and satisfying dish. A few of my other preferred dishes are the sautéed green beans, mango shrimp and poached tilapia work bok choy. Service here is top notched.  As busy as they get, they always try to be fast and not show that they are not being overbearing.

This is a very standardized Chinese restaurant. nothing fancy here. The portions are reasonable and the food is really delicious. I am not sure why its always empty i think the location is not the best. Its very clean and like i said earlier the food is really what you'd expect from your typical chines restaurant.

BYOB :) Delicious and flavorful food. Love getting the family style options with bigger groups, but today  I noticed the lunch prices on the back of the menu and omg I need to come back sometime soon and get an individual entree. I have loved everything I've ever tried there so far and I will def be back soon.

Wanted fried rice for dinner tonight. Open Yelp app and went off recommendations. BingoFirst time here at Mr Wok. Parking lot was full and over flow next door. The place was packed and people waiting. The place smelled awesome, all that wonderful food coming out of the kitchen. The price was very reasonable for fried rice, l will be returning, they have alot of items that will fit my diet.ConsNo utensils ln my to go order. l will let that slide.

THE BEST CHINESE FOOD IN TOWN !!!  Ingredients are fresh... sauces are not saturated with MSG...  Jack the owner is really friendly and treats everybody like family.  Great service.  My family and I have eaten there at least once a week for the past several years.   All the dishes are delicious and very reasonably priced considering there's a lot of care that goes into preparing them.  Highly recommend it.

First time here on Saturday and it definitely won't be the last! The duck here was delicious! Crunchy skin and succulent, tender meat...it was so mouth-watering good! My group ordered ordered two ducks and for the duck bones, we got them to do both the stir fry and the soup. The soup was great but the stir fry was even better! The nice thing about this place is that if you don't want to order duck, they have a regular menu as well that offers plenty options. Oh, and it's BYOB, so bring a bottle of wine, eat some duck, and have a good time!!! :)

Oh man. Every other time I go to DFW I go here and get a Peking Duck and stuff my face with it. There really are no other words of the joy that my mouth feels. It's like the happiest Chewbaca, but like MORE. You know how sometimes when you have a secret it's like even more precious and joyful. It's like a secret joy. It's contained inside. Okay, stop this nonsense Sarang. Anyways, point being, it's great. Food is fresh, it's not a huge place, it's one big room with booths around the edge and tables in the center, probably not much more than 25 tables, but it stays pretty full. If you want the Peking Duck, call ahead and they'll be sure to reserve one for you. Next time, I'm gonna need to go with 4 people because I want to try the Beggar's Chicken but not at the cost of not having the Peking Duck. MMMDELICIOUS.

I was very disappointed. After all the reviews i had really built this place up to be let so far down.We ate tonight Wednesday about 5pm only 1 other customer when we arrived.All the items we ordered had so much filler vegetables or fruit very little meat (see pics) I got the signature dish Mango shrimp there were 5 shrimp and about 2 full mangos so much mango made the dish entirely cold.  Daughter got the Mongolian beef not spicy at all and i would say about 1/4 cup meat rest was vegetables then hubby got the curry beef with a complete full onion and what tasted like dried peas not fully hydrated. The fried rice was not fried at all it was older rice chewy mixed with soy sauce nothing else.  Nobody came to check on us for drinks or how we were doing at anytime. Very disappointed and will not give a second chance was not worth it.

Before our Chinese born roommate left America for a life abroad, he wanted to show us what Peking Duck tasted like. True, he was inspired to show us this because of an episode of Hannibal, but we appreciated the gesture anyways. If you're going here for the duck, make sure that you call in ahead of time. And one duck is best to be split between 3 to 4 people. Trust me, those little things end producing a shitload of meat, spread across 3 courses of preparations of them. I seriously wish that I could remember the names of each concoction throughout the meal, but the taco-like part was my favorite, followed by the soup. And, as the large group of Chinese business men sat down at the table next to us, we learned two important things about Mr. Wok. (1) It's BYOB. This group of 10 businessmen probably had 3 cases of beer with them, so shit was 'bout to get rowdy. (2) The local Chinese clientele in the Plano/Richardson area approve of the food and how it's presented at Mr. Wok. That is priceless when deciding where to eat.All in all, this place was so fantastic that I'm having cravings right now, and I rarely eat meat. If you're looking for Peking duck, this is where to go in the Plano/Richardson area. Everything is expertly prepared, cooked, and presented.

Really juicy and delicious Peking duck! Skin was crispy and at the same time it melted in my mouth.  If you order the Peking duck they will either stir fry or make a soup with the left over.  Mapo tofu was also excellent.

Mr. Wok is hands down my number one place to go for Peking duck. With table side carving of the duck, it's a guarantee you'll get that crispy skin you came for in the first place! If duck is not your thing, there are plenty of other dishes that won't disappoint. Try the "Crispy Tangy Beef", another dish I get all the time.This place is small so be prepared to wait if you don't have reservations. It seems like it was a Pizza Hut at one point that have been renovated into a Chinese restaurant. Parking is also small but they allow parking at a nearby lot just down the street.

I was soooo excited for this!! I heard about this place from 2 different people- they also advised that we needed to set a reservation on a duck at least 8 hours ahead.I set a reservation a day beforehand with a pleasant woman and we arrived at 745PM and were sat about 5-10 mins after. It seemed very busy and hectic but our server was super nice and friendly!We didn't get anything besides the duck as it was a 2 course entree and there were only 2 of us. Good thing too, we couldn't finish everything!The owner came out with the duck and started carving quickly while the aroma filled a bubble around us. omgsh it smelled SOOO good!! After he finished, he asked us how we wanted our second course- stir fry or bones soup. We asked for both so we got half portions of each!We also opted for the buns (between buns and crepes). The buns were so fluffy and white! I was a little disappointed because the buns were pretty cold by the time the duck was set on our table-carved and ready.They brought out the buns super early too. It would have been AMAZING if the buns were hot. But that's my only takeaway on the first course.The duck skin was so crispy and fatty and delicious!! The meat was so juicy and I enjoyed every single bite!! The stir fry was with some bitter/pickled cabbage which I'm not the biggest fan of. I didn't like this too much except that the duck skin was even crispier which was so much more amazing!I liked the soup more because the taste of the cabbage was a bit more muted and not as overwhelming. Bottom line: The peking duck here is absolutely amazing. The service is fast and friendly. And between 2 people- 20$ for a very very filling delicious dinner? Worth.

Mr. Wok never dissappoints. Get the seared edaname and pork dumplings for starters. Peking duck is a must for first timers...followed with the soup. Green beans are excellent too. I liked combo fried rice as well and makes good leftovers. BYOB!!!

I would rate this more of a 3.5 out of 5 stars overallll. Came here for my sister's boyfriend's birthday and I really enjoyed the low key, family style portion sized Chinese food. The restaurant use to be an old Pizza Hut which I was able to visualize after being told so. Parking spots are very limited and confusing so just keep your eyes opened due to the confined space. We ordered sooo many dishes and I love the fact that it's byob (poppp as many bottles without feeling guilty...lol). My favorite out of the 6 dishes (wish I knew the correct names) was the Peking duck, vegetable noodle soup, and this sautéed green onion with beef. Now I'm sure you've noticed how popular the Peking duck entree is according to the past reviews so make sure you preorder the duck at least 48 hours before dining at the establishment. I really liked the buns and crepes intended to consume with the duck. I feel as if the Peking duck was somewhat on the bland side. I wasn't very impressed with duck ... maybe I set the bar too high? I really enjoyed the authentic step up from ramen vegetable noodle soup dish which is large enough to share between 4 ppl (as an appetizer of course)!Overall: I thought this place was mediocre. I'll probably return but most likely won't. I was pretty disappointed after my first time dining at Mr. Wok. Hopefully, it'll all change after my next visit.

Could've easily been a five, but the ridiculous wait knocks it down a star. We had a reservation at 7:30, and didn't get seated until 8:30...why offer reservations then?! That perplexes me til this day. But the manager was very apologetic and offered us a free appetizer because of the wait. I was still a little annoyed by the wait, but the food made me forget all about it. We got 2 of the Peking Ducks, and it was out of this world! They do a tableside carving, so you get a meal and show all in one. They serve you the meat and skin with steamed buns and tortillas. Then they make you either a soup or stir fry from the leftover bones. Talking about getting your money's worth. We got one of each, and I prefer the soup over the stir fry. It was just refreshing after all that meat and carbs! The stir fry wasn't all too bad though. It was just a lot of heavy eating. Safe to say I was in a food coma afterwards. The duck was moist, the skin SUPER crispy, and the service impeccable (except for the wait, but it was a busy night so I'll let it go). This place is an hour from us, yes an hour. So probably won't be coming back in the near future. But definitely will have to go back to try out their Beggar's Chicken. You have to call in advance to place the order though since they don't make extras!

This is a really unique place.  You can get good Chinese food in a lot of places, but none of the other ones I have ever been to can do a DUCK like these guys.If you call ahead, you can order a Peking Duck that will knock your socks off.  Not only do they serve it in a really cool way, they will make fried rice, soup, and other things with it after the table presentation.It looks like an old pizza hut from the outside (it was one) but don't let that fool you.  They are always busy and the food and service are why.  It's also very reasonable for a great place.Jack is the GM and he's super friendly and professional.  Don't miss this place.

This place has great reviews on yelp so I had to try it out. If you want to get a seat, especially during the weekends, you have to call for reservations ahead of time. Sometimes even a day in advance.We were seated right away. The restaurant itself is small. The building kind of looks like an old Pizza Hut, but they decorated it pretty nicely in there.They have a full menu but what great is that the menu tells you which dishes are their Signature Dishes. I would recommend ordering any of their signature dishes. My crew ordered the Peking Duck, the Sesame Chicken and the Banana-Chocolate Spring Rolls. There are certain dishes you have to reserve a day or two in advance such as the Peking Duck and the Beggar's Chicken. My crew loved the Peking Duck. They cut it into small pieces in front of you. You eat it with pork buns, a sauce and vegetables. They take the remaining pieces and make it into a smaller dish with vegetables and a soup. I personally didn't eat any of the duck because I don't like duck. However, if it counts at all, my crew ate all of their dishes to the bone. I ate the sesame chicken. The dish was ok. I really should've ordered something with more flavors but it sounded good on the menu and it was a signature dish. Not too many different flavors with the sesame chicken. The dessert was pretty good. Super crunchy and sweet. Plenty of banana and chocolate in each bite. It comes with a caramel dip. All in all this place is pretty good. Everyone in the room seemed to be in awe of the two signature dishes...Peking duck and Beggars chicken. It was pretty cool how they presented these two dishes. As for the other dishes on the menu, I wasn't as pleased. I can only say for the sesame chicken but I wish it had more flavor. The dessert was bomb though. I would definitely recommend eating here!

Wow!! From the outside and inside you can see Mr. Wok doesn't look like much, but don't let that fool you. This is a hidden gem tucked aside for those adventurous to search for. Do yourself a favor and end your search for amazing food here. Grab a group of friends, reserve a table, and reserve a Peking duck!Coming all the way from the Oak Lawn area of Dallas to Plano I expected nice food, but I have to say my mind was blown!! Now I used to live in Houston and visit their Chinatown all the time. I know what great food is and this my friends is great food!! Honestly one of the best if not the best Peking duck I've ever had!! We had our duck cut table side by the owner himself, Jack. The explained how the ducks are marinated the night before and cooked fresh when you order it. Jack shared with me a secret that makes the duck skin extra crispy and the mean lean which I'll just say I'd have to agree that it works. The skin is crisper than others and the meat lean.The remaining duck meat on the bones was then used to be stir-fried into an equally nice dish. Lots of flavor with one of the several ingredients Jack shared being garlic. We also had the Mr Wok sampler of appetizers which was tasty, but thinking back I wish I had more belly room saved for the Peking duck.There was plenty of parking and seating when we came but it quickly changed and was packed with a line and little parking by the time we left. I'd recommend having a reservation or coming early. Long story short: great service, legit food, and cool experience.
Best Chinese food hands down in Plano Texas. Get the duck and try the second portion stir fried. The dumplings are the bomb.

Made reservation way advance for my moms birthday. Very busy  hole in the wall. The place is very crowed to get around. Not handicap friendly. It was difficult to guide my dad around in the wheelchair. I felt bad to ask people to move for us. We finally set down and it took and hour and half to get our pecking duck. We order some appetizers and it took 30 mins to get it. We also order other side dishes and they missed two dishes and we told  them to cancel it. We can't wait any longer. The service was horrible. The poor kid was running around frantically. There was two server and one person to cut the duck. Way under staff. The owner seems she doesn't care at all and stay at the front and not help the tables. The waiter just ignore our table and didn't greet us and just ask rudely are you ready to order. The food was fantastic but the service was down hill. Will not come back until they figure out their wait staff.

I came for lunch and the service and prices are awesome! Lunch meal is $5.75 - $5.95 for egg roll or egg drop soup, entree and rice. I subbed fried rice for white rice. I had the Szechwan beef. Sauce was great with a lot of veggies. Unfortunately, not much beef which I understand for the price. It was a HUGE portion so I had the leftovers for dinner. I chose the egg drop soup instead of the egg roll. It was a different broth and consistency than what I'm used to but thought it was very good. It also included some veggies which was a great surprise. Also had an order of crab rangoon that was eh. Not terrible but not fantastic. My coworker had the pad thai which he did not care for but this is not a Thai restaurant. Stick with the Chinese dishes. I will return for lunch and try new dishes. For the price, how could you not?!

I saw great reviews on Yelp and was so excited to try the Peking duck. However, after trying the duck, I felt deceived and duped because it was terrible. The meat was dry and extremely bland. They cut off about 50% meat off the whole duck in front of you to eat with the buns, then they took the remaining to the back to make you a "second course", which really is just the chopped up remains and stirred fried. See the picture here -- it looks as bad as it tasted. I was served white rice with the duck but the rice was old, cold, and hard. On top of the bad food, the place was filthy. I looked up the ceiling and there were dusts formed all over the place. It looked like they haven't cleaned in decades. We sat by the window and the blinds were just as filthy. If the front of the restaurant is like this, I can't imagine how dirty it would be in the back. All in all, this is one of the worst restaurants I've been to. It was a waste of money! $35 for a dried up duck.9/9/2016 - this is in response to Jack's (business owner/manager/duck carver) comment to my review. Hi Jack, Thanks for your response but your assumption is incorrect. I'm used to flavorful & tender duck meat even after the fat has been rendered. Yours tasted like you didn't only strip the fat but also everything else with it. All I tasted was a doughy bun with hoisin sauce filled with rubbery duck meat. I understand that you might not like negative feedback but please don't proceed to imply what I'm used to in order to undermine my review. Every Yelper has the right to express their opinion and let the reader decide for themselves whether to try your restaurant.

Waste of money!!!!Came here tonight because my wife was at The hospital down the road and this was her last meal since she couldn't eat anything past midnight and ordered King Pao Chicken. We got the dinner daily special since we didn't want a ton of food and that was a mistake. Size wise, it's a lot of food. However what is actually put in the meal is a joke. Tons and I mean tons of bamboo shoots, (I actually filled my second opening in the togo box full of them and still had some) lots of peanuts, peas, and minced thigh chicken meat. I threw my food away after I gave up trying to take a bite of food without bamboo shoots. Never coming back. So sad too as I am only 15 minutes away normally.

We made a reservation and arrived well before our reservation time. We still had to wait 20 mins after our reservation time to be seated. What's the point in making a reservation?Decor: 3.5/5-Looks like it use to be a Pizza Hut inside? -The red booth seats look comfy however we sat at the round table which can comfortably seat 6 without obstructing traffic. The round tables can seat up to 10, maybe more. Service: 4/5Food: 4/5-The begger's chicken was unique and came in a huge loaf of bread. The chicken was moist and tender yet nothing to brag about. This was about $37.-Peking duck was roughly $25 each and more worth it than the beggar's chicken-Calamari app is a must however it is slightly on the salty side-Singaporean rice noodles were standard, nothing to brag about-Combination Fried Rice was great. Wish I had gotten two orders of that. Will be returning for the sizzling shrimp and scallop dish

Food - 3Service - 4Value - 3I feel like the last couple of times I've come here that the food just isn't as good as it used to be and the prices feel like they keep going up too.  The Peking duck seemed dry the last two times and the Beggar's Chicken also seemed a tad try the last two times as well.  Because this place is so popular, it can also get quite crowded on the weekend for dinner and then you end up with some fairly cramped quarters from time to time.

Great and affordable place to come for some Peking duck - just remember to call ahead to order the duck. The duck is juicy with nice crispy skin,.  We get the stir fry duck bones, which are a pain to eat but tasty and you can't go wrong with the pancakes.  However some of the sides are a little weak.  Th sauteed egg plant came swimming in sauce which we didn't appreciate.  Next time I want to try the begger's chicken but you need to order a couple of days in advance.

We had 2 roasted duck, mango shrimp, and Beijing beef. Each of the ducks leftover bones were used as a stir fry dish & duck soup. The duck was really flavorful but I wish the duck skin was crispier. The mango shrimp was weird, it all just tasted like seafood (that nasty seafood taste) & the shrimp was soft in batter. As for the Beijing beef, it was really good!! I liked the duck soup because it was really hearty with all the herbs but the duck stir fry just made the duck kinda dry. Overall the duck is really good & fresh! The server was really friendly.

We made reservation around 4pm on Saturday and was ecstatic they can accommodate us with a 7:30 reservation. The restaurant is not very big and the decor is dated but it gives you a warm family feel. I did a lot of yelping and asking around so I knew exactly what we were going to get. We went with the Peking Duck with the stir fry, Crispy Red Snapper, Combination Fried Rice, Parmesan Prawn, and Water Spinach with Beef. The Peking Duck was exceptional, everyone at the table loved it. The guy who cut our duck was welcoming and talkative which made the whole experience even better. The only critique I would have is that the water spinach and beef was a little salty and had an overwhelming taste of oyster sauce. However, everything else was great. I would definitely recommend Mr.Wok to my friends and family.  Important: You must make reservation if you don't want to wait or get turned away and do not skip out on the Peking Duck!!!!
This place is amazing. I like the Peking duck, the chicken, and the sweet and sour fish. They do need reservation and advance notice for the duck/special chicken.

Primarily came for the Peking duck! You must call in and order in advance. The Peking duck comes with the buns, veggies, and hoisin sauce. You can always order more buns if needed too. There's also a choice of roti/pancake instead of buns. The meat is really tender and fresh. The skin is perfectly crispy. There's a person that serves you the duck and slices the meats for your at your table. At the end of your dinner you get a choice between two different soups. The one we had was really light. It was a good balance with all the food we had.Orange chicken and crispy tango beef are my other two favorite meat side dishes. If you're a fan of the mayo mango shrimp, I wouldn't suggest getting it here. It's not my favorite. There's a lot of mango versus shrimp. It's BYOB as well!I went with about 8 people. We got two Peking duck orders and 9 different plates. Splitting it evenly between everyone it was about $23 give or take. It's well worth it! You definitely leave the restaurant with a food coma.

Once again had an incredible meal there!!!  The sizzling seafood skillet is fantastic. All3 of us enjoyed our entrees. Also, out server Allison was the best ever. Friendly, cheerful and playful. She made sure to not put our entrees in to be cooked until 5 or 10 minutes after our appetizers arrived. A rare thing. Highly recommended to be sure!!!

Best Peking Duck in Dallas, hands down.Everything I've tried here is good but honestly, the Peking Duck just steals the show.  They bring out the roasted duck whole and slice it up table-side.  I think it may have been the owner who brought out our duck and he was so nice, taking the time to explain how they're able to get the skin so incredibly crispy while keeping the meat tender and juicy.  The dish comes with either pancakes or steamed buns (my preference).  Grab one of those piping hot buns and layer in some amazing duck meat, crispy skin, hoisin sauce, and scallions, and you've got the most amazing bite ever. Bonus!  They'll take the bones and leftover meat and make you a second (very large) duck dish-- either a stir fry or soup.  Can't beat that!

Absolutely ridiculous!! We just got our order dropped off. Waited a few hours, ordered Kung Pao Chicken, Almond Chicken, wontons, and chicken chow mein. dishes....and some have NO CHICKEN! To top it off we got TWO chicken less Kung Pao dishes, and not our Almond Chicken!! They literally are full of disgusting water chestnuts and peanuts! Not one piece of chicken! Only the chow mein had chicken and the wontons are the only thing not messed up... We're beyond livid with this and cannot believe someone thought this was acceptable to send out. We ordered through a delivery service, and the place is now closed so there's nothing we can do at this time. I really urge someone to be held accountable for this cause I have never in my life ran into something this bad. We don't even understand how this place has so many stars?!?

Sometimes they're on and others...I've experienced the best fried rice and will go back a month or so later and the rice is hard, they're out of eggs, or the ribs are hard and tough as heck! Not sure what the inconsistency is about but...

If you are ever in the mood for pei king duck, this is the place you need to go, and FYI you need to order the duck in advance before you go.I went to dinner here with 3 friends and we got 1 duck and 3 side dishes which was more then enough food. We ordered water spinach, salt and pepper shrimp, and tofu family style with pork. With the duck the server cuts it right in front of you and it comes with buns and sauce to wrap the duck with. The duck bones and remaining meat can either be used for a soup or stir fry- we chose stir fry. The duck was so delicious, it's very hard to get duck so juicy and flavorful but this place did it, I was so impressed with the duck. Everything else their was subpar, but the duck is a must! The stir fry duck was a little salty and everything else was over cooked. The tofu with pork was good, but again on the saltier side. Everything comes with rice though! The service here is so unstaffed. They were so busy even on a Thursday night that it took a long time to get anything we asked for, even our check.

Eggplant stir fried added shredded pork and fried tofu EXCELLENTBeggar's Chicken just okPeking duck just ok. Mango shrimp surprisingly goodRed snapper fried excellentRed snapper steamed excellentPot stickers just ok Bok choy shitake mushroom very goodGreen beans fried with tofu very good Shrimp fried rice very goodService here always goodFried donuts with banana fillings good

The other reviews and late dinner with some close friends led to high expectations.One thing that's kinda cool is this place is an old converted Pizza Hut - you know the actual restaurant where going as a kid to get pizza with the family was an experience. Anyway, rose-tinted memories of mediocre pizza are now replaced with quite excellent Chinese food with the always appreciated BYOB option.I got the wonton soup as a starter which had great broth and good wontons. Not a bad start. For my main course I went with the Szechwan Chicken. It was pretty tasty but I'll be honest I was a bit disappointed as I expected more. I couldn't tell if they used real Szechwan Peppercorn which is supposed to numb your tongue a bit - first time trying it. There was too much sauce where I prefer a drier style.Still, my business dinner companions enjoyed their meal and they live close by so this is still a great option in Eastern Plano / North Dallas.

Oh man, one of our new favorites --- for the entire family. It's certainly an eating experience ordering the peking duck. It's as authentic as you can get here in the states. It feels like a hole-in-the-wall place when you drive up and even when you're inside, but that's what makes the atmosphere so great. Mr. Wok has been recognized time and time again in Dallas, and there's many reasons behind that. Every dish we've had has been amazing - full of flavor and delicious. Keep in mind that the restaurant is small - reservations are preferred with a large enough party, parking is limited, and it's a converted Pizza Hut building or something like that. If you know this information and visit for the atmosphere, food, and service, and not judge by appearance, it's a 5-star dining experience
Best Peking duck in the DFW and much cheaper. The restaurant is always packed so call in advance.
Pleasant spot, nice staff not expensiveDuck at dinner may be the treat  described belowbut lunch was sugary gloppy '60's american/cantonesethat I can better from the freezer at Kroger's
This place is amazing I'm new in town and found this place, the food is fantastic juicy freshly cooked and the service was great. I'm for sure coming here everyday!

I've lived in Dallas for a little over 10 years and always chose Thai or Vietnamese over Chinese since my Chinese restaurant experiences had been ho-hum at best. Until today. This place is small (in a former Pizza Hut) with 12 tables. Had the appetizer sampler which found us saying Wow, oooo, try this one. Got the Crispy Tangy Beef with fried rice and it was the Japanese shorter grain rice with a good chew and flavor. Beef was tender, green beans were fresh and crisp. We saw 2 tables get the beautiful Peking duck and a table get the Beggar's Chicken. The carver/waiter offered the mallet to one of the diners who whacked the bread dome over and over with no success. I clapped and cheered him on and the rest of the diners joined in - success! We will be back. Loved it!

This was our first time at Mr. Wok and it was a great dining experience.  We ordered the Peking duck and it was fantastic!  With table side carving, the duck was tender, had very little fat, and the skin was so crispy.  Our waitress was very nice and recommended we use the bones for stir fry and soup.  I loved the stir fry, the mustard green was crunchy and always one of my favorite ingredients in any dish.  The soup needed some flavoring, if you add a little salt, it's great and a nice ending to any meal.  Service was excellent.

There are two places in DFW I would order peking duck from: Mr. Wok and Beijing Brothers in Coppell. Mr. Wok has been around longer, but I did not try their duck until recently. Their meat was not gamey when freshly carved and served. However, the stir fry (made with leftover meat) did taste gamey... but it could just be me, as I am very sensitive. I recommend calling ahead to pre-order, since they are known for this dish and sell out quickly. I also tried their whole fried fish, and loved it. It was crispy on the outside and tender and juicy on the inside. The sauce poured over the fish was sweet and tangy. Overall, this is a good place for a casual family dinner. It looks pretty run-down, so it's not the most ideal place for a date or a girls' night out. Prices are a little higher than other Chinese restaurants but still reasonable, considering most of their dishes are shareable. Service can be hit or miss, depending on how busy they are.

Went here based on the reviews.  I've been several times and all visits have been great to good to fair - seemingly in that order - so I don't know if I should go back!  Crab rangoons are big!  The last time I ordered lunch to go, the rice was crunchy, which kind of ruined my sesame chicken.  I will probably give them another chance, but it may be a while.

Hands down one of the top 3 Chinese places I have been to.  Please you must try Mr Wok if you haven't before.First off, the fact that traditional Chinese families (think 3-4 generations all together) come here for dinners validate this place is legit.  Top that off with a team of servers who have been here (and know the menu well) a while, you can trust their recommendations.  Also VERY affordable!! Food - cha Han fried rice is legit. The duck is a MUST get. Crispy beef is also very good. The egg foo young, basil noodles, sesame chicken, orange chicken, mango shrimp are all....good but not great. Can't wait to try the other dishes.Parking can be tough, this is BYOB so keeps your bill down! Heard "meh" reviews with Beggar Chicken.Please if you're considering this place, do your taste buds a favor and just come!

Modern take on classic Chinese dishes,Mr. Wok does not disappoint. FromThe Beijing Duck that is carved and served in a wonton to a crispy beef that melts in your mouth, this quaint location needs a reservation on weekends. They have several speciality dishes and we try a different one each time we go. If the wait is too long, order take out. It travels well.

The peking duck experience here was awesome. They carve the duck at your table and will explain on how they made the duck. On top of that, the duck was tasty which just completes the experience. I would totally recommend on taking a date here especially if they never had peking duck before. But be sure to call ahead of time to make sure they have ducks though since they're made in a limited quantity.

Love this place and eat there ever so often. The Peking duck is wonderful and some of our party has had it in Beijing. The food has always been often but last night our waiter sucked. We got appetizer plates and for 3 adults he brought out 2 dinner plates. WTF was I supposed to use? The little ap plate evidently. He never came back to refill water. We had to flag him down after 10 mins looking for him. We have never had him before. Hope we never have him again. We have had the beautiful red headed woman and another man and always been pleased but this guy was terribleThe guy was a tall, med brown haired white guy about mid 20 s, with glasses

I'm from CA and when I'm in town visiting family I have to order thePeking duck.  I can eat the buns that come with the order alone it's fluffy, airy, semi sweetened.  The duck skin is crispy and holds a lot of flavor.

This place is great. You should order the duck a day early to assure you get one.  It is byob but that just makes it really inexpensive.  The duck comes with pancakes (like tortillas), scallions, and plum sauce.  The extra bones are made into either a stir fry or soup.  We've gotten the stir fry both times.  We had lots of leftovers both times.  The service is great and they are really nice.  The only reason for a missing star is because the table covers are stained and it makes it seem dirty, but it was not.  Some cloth table covers would really dress up the place instead of the hard plastic stained ones.  We will definitely be back again for the best duck ever!

Get the duck! It needs to be ordered in advance just like the Beggar's Chicken. I went with a group of friends and we ordered ahead for both which would have been plenty for all six of us but we decided to also try the Orange Peel Beef, Chicken Chow Fun, and Bok Choy. Everything was amazing but the duck was probably my favorite. They bring out the whole duck and the server cuts it up and serves the meat and crispy skin on a platter along with wraps, veggies and hoisin sauce for part 1. For part 2, they use the rest of the duck and prepare it either in a soup or stir fry based on your preference. We did the stir fry and it was delicious - lots of garlic. The chicken dish is quite a show and the meat comes out very moist since they roast it for 22 hours within the bread, banana and lotus leaves, and aluminum foil. Friendly service too! We'll definitely go back.

Small restaurant on 14th street. They're well known for their Peking duck, which I was hoping to try.Unfortunately, since this was a spur of the moment thing, I didn't pre-order one and was just hoping to get one of their extra ones they sell first-come-first-serve.Well, unfortunately not....Fortunately their other food turns out to be pretty good as well.We tried their Cantonese crispy noodles, puffed shrimp, mango shrimp and pot stickers.The Cantonese crispy noodles are not like the birds nest noodles at most Chinese restaurants, but almost as thick as spaghetti and, for a lack of a better word, a fluffy crispy. Very interesting and also very tasty. It came with a dark sauce, veggies and your choice of a protein. The sauce was pretty mild (I usually prefer spicier fare), but still tasted good.The pot stickers were delicious, filled with cabbage and pork, with a nice bite.The puffed shrimp was shrimp bis in a puffed up dough, also very good.The mango shrimp comes in a bowl made with wonton dough and filled with cold mange, a sweet sauce and crispy fried shrimp on top. Not bad, but a little sweet for my taste.Overall a very good meal and I'll definitely come back, and this this time I'll call-ahead for a duck. Oh, and it's a pretty small place, so you may wait a little to be seated during rush times.

Friendly staff but the food was awful! I ordered the shrimp in lobster sauce, which came out as a clumpy mess. The steamed rice was overcooked. The pork egg roll was cold on the inside so it was probably just reheated. I had high hopes based on previous reviews but I won't be back.

Attentive service.All of the quality of food was exceptional as was the presentation. We thoroughly enjoyed this meal. This place is consistent and we will return again soon.Adjacent table ordered several Peking ducks. They were carved at the table and the experience looked incredible.

Jack,Don't get me wrong, your place do have good peking duck and have been there a few times.I call at 1 pm but all your server say was no table that fits 15 people and never said anything about tables were being reserve nor anything else then hung up. That's what made me upset, which if you were in my shoes would be too. Also the person who call back was my bro, so that can get an answer from another person.
One of my all time favorite places for the last 13 years! We love Jack the owner also! Do yourself a favor and eat here!

The peking duck was fantastic! One duck is enough to serve 4 people .  You can serve the rest of the duck two ways. I prefer stir fry instead of soup. Other things were pretty good too.  I testify that they serve authentic Chinese food!Be sure to make a reservation on weeknights. You'll need to reserve a duck when make the reservation. Just try everything!

This was a very nice experience.  A busy place.  Food was great.  Portions are large enough to share.  There were 2 of us.  Had an appetizer and one meal and still had leftovers.  They do have a lazy Susan in the middle of 4 large table to serve family style.  Those table seat 10 comfortably.  Nice staff.  There specialty is Duck.  This is something you have to call and make sure they have, if not you can order it.  Large groups are best to make reservations.  Will definitely go again.

Still going strong and still the best Peking duck in Texas. Service was great. Erick was our waiter and he was on the ball throughout the night. The owner Jack made recommendation for dishes in addition to the duck, which is the way to go if you are a large group.
Peking Duck was amazing. Crispy skin.  Great flavor. Mango shrimp was just okay. Not enough shrimp. Too sweet for my palate. Will definitely return.
Since we took it to go, this review is solely on the food and the taste. Effing delicious. Crispy skin, juicy meat. No need to explain. Reserve yours now and try it!
Yum yum and yum.  I've been here twice now.  Reservations definitely required.  Food is amazing.  Everything was scrumptious.

This place was highly recommended for their Orange Chicken. When we were seated we noticed how greasy dirty the fans were and tablecloth was stained. We ordered Mongolian Beef and received a plate of mainly sliced onions and beef pieces so small you couldn't pick it up with a fork. Not much heat or flavor either. The Orange Chicken was tough and tasted like it had been cooked some time before we ordered it and sauce added and reheated. We should have sent it back but the less than $20 tab wasn't worth it. Will probably not return.

When we drove up to this place, we saw a tiny lil building with a parking lot full of cars. Who would've thought that such amazing food would be here?? We ordered the peking duck, beggars chicken and fried red snapper. The duck needs to be ordered 1 day in advance, while the chicken needs to be ordered 2 days in advance so keep that in mind if you plan on coming here. The first thing we got was the duck, which came whole as the carver delicately slices off thin layers of the crispy skin and the tender meat underneath. We had our duck with the steamed buns, hoisin sauce and green onions. The skin was so flavorful and crispy. The meat was soft and meaty. Totally delicious. This has got to be one of the best peking ducks I've ever had ! After carving the duck, he asked if we wanted it stir fried or cooked in a soup. We selected the stir fry option and we were so happy with our choice. The duck came out crispy and sooo flavorful! It was stir fried with onions and these pickled veggies. It was amazing! Next came the beggar's chicken, which was served in this giant hard bread and the waiter asked if anyone wants to try to crack it open. Inside it was a foil wrapped whole chicken stuffed with sticky rice. The upper portion of the chicken was quite bland and dry but as you dig deeper, you'll find the juices that give it a good bit of flavor. The flavor was  a bit too herby for us so we weren't too crazy about this dish, it was cool for the experience though.Lastly, we had the fried red snapper. Wow, this dish was beautiful! It was a huge, meaty fish that had this meat sauce poured over it. Can't quite describe the sauce but it was yummy! The fish was crispy and flavorful and surprisingly, this was only $25 for an extra large! (although I'm not sure if we're just really hungry but the XL wasn't that big as we ate the whole thing between 4 people)Overall, we had a wonderful experience coming here. The food was great and I would recommend the duck & the snapper to anybody. I wouldn't go back for the chicken but it is a good filler if you are trying to feed more people.

I've been here twice and each time I was disappointed. The food is mediocre at best.Peking duck w/buns: The duck is dry and bland. The buns were stuck together and would rip apart. The hoisin sauce is hoisin sauce, always good. As you are being served the duck you are told that it is a high quality lean duck. All I'm saying is I don't care if it is an organic, fair trade, humane certified full beaked pond roaming lean duck that gets daily massages - if you dry it out you've ruined it. Lean ducks should still be juicy and rich when made properly.Broccoli beef: I didn't enjoy it and don't recommend it.

Not bad but not the greatest Chinese food I had. This place is tiny so expect a wait if you want to eat in. If not, you're better off getting take out. Service here isn't very attentive but it's doable. I see they're trying their best. The food has been inconsistent between the two times we visited. On our first visit, food was great. But this second time, most of of food came out cold or not up to par like our first time. Shrimp fried rice came out cold and the crispy beef had too much sauce. The first time we ordered the fried snapper and that was great. But if you don't want to pick at the bones the thai sole is delicious and comes without bones. Haven't had the chance to try the peking duck but it looks great. I'll probably be back again but I'm still on the lookout for a more authentic Chinese place.

This is the second time I've been here and it just gets better!  The restaurant is pretty small and they have a small staff so there is normally a bit of waiting involved.  That kind of thing rarely bothers me so I don't think it's a big deal but I know some people might get annoyed.  I came in a party of 6 and we all shared the appetizers of dumplings (delicious, fresh, and hot) and lettuce wraps.  We also got the Peking Duck and Beggar's Chicken (both of which you need to reserve 24 hours in advance due to the way they cook it).  The Peking duck is carved table side and the skin is crispy, the meat is juicy and it is absolutely amazing.  It comes with very thin pancakes/tortillas to wrap the duck in with hoisin sauce and onions.  Then you get the choice of what you would like them to do with the rest of the meat still on the bone (stir fry or soup).  We've gotten the stir fry both times and it is amazing in its own!  Just the duck can feed two people.  The Beggar's Chicken comes encased in a bread bowl that they crack open at your table (they'll even let you do it if you want to)!  The chicken inside is wrapped in foil and bamboo leaves so it will cook and seal in all the juices with the sticky rice.  The chicken is SO tender you scoop it out with a spoon!  Overall it is by far 5 stars!  I can't wait to come again, maybe during lunch since their lunch prices look really good!

Mr. Wok, I would like to personally thank you for letting me make a fool of myself in front of the entire restaurant while I was trying to crack open the bread for the beggars chicken we ordered. I then watched you with your fancy shears cut open the bread to reveal a beautiful bird wrapped in leaves. The chicken was ridiculously tender and the sticky rice filling was amazing. The chicken was huge and we ended up taking it to go and it was 2 containers worth (not filled all the way). My dad (Chinese food connoisseur) was pleased with the way it tasted, the last time he had it was in China and he hasn't been able to find a place that served it. We also ordered the Peking duck which was delicious, I personally like getting the buns over the pancakes. The pancakes are fine but I don't like how hard they are to peel apart and its just one big lump of pancake. For our second duck course we got the soup this time which was really great considering we ate soo much food, it was light and flavorful. It had some noodles and some cabbage added to the broth. The stir fry is a little more filling and messy but there is more flavor. We also ordered some eggplant in garlic sauce and man that was really good, it wasn't what I was expecting. I was thinking it'll be some garlic on eggplant but it was a deep and dark flavorful garlicky sauce, it is totally worth trying. We also ordered fried calamari and pot stickers. The pot stickers were the typical frozen to pan, nothing special; not worth ordering. The calamari was fried perfectly and had an intense but not too strong garlic flavor. We came here on a Wednesday night and every table was taken (thankfully we had a reservation). Ducks were flying out of the kitchen every 10 minutes, I think I saw at least 15 ducks being served while I was there, this place is obviously known for their peking ducks. The service was fine and it was an overall great experience, I highly recommend this restaurant!

I wish this place was much closer to me in Ft Worth !  The Peking duck is unbelievable and you get a second course with the duck whether it's stir fry or soup. I've been here twice and literally everybody gets a duck!  Definitely call in advance to make sure you have a duck that day! I would recommend giving a call 24 hours in advance!

I love this place, they make the best Peking duck I've had in Texas. They bring it table-side and carve it right next to your table. The skin is crispy. The meat is juicy and tender. It's exactly how a duck should be made. They also make a second dish out of the bones, either a stir fry or a soup. The stir fry option is a bit too heavy for me after eating all of the duck meat from the first dish so I prefer the soup option.The only other thing I've had here is their corn and crap soup which is also really delicious.They are very popular so expect a wait if you come during peak hours. If you know you want duck, be sure to reserve one ahead of time since they sometimes run out if you come late.

Best Peking duck in town. Small cozy place. Our favorite is the Peking duck with buns but make sure to make your reservation a day in advance or no duck for you. Also they only serve it on weekends. Another great dish is beggar's chicken.

I tried this Resturant base on all the good reviews on Yelp. They must have paid Yelp to filter all the bad reviews. 4 stars?... Are  you kidding, I was very disappointed in the food. We ordered the Peking duck and it was terrible, the skin had a thick layer of fat on it, the ideal Peking duck is not suppose to have fat on the skin, it suppose to be roast and bake until all fat are melted and leave a crunchy skin. The schuwan beef is a joke, the beef was chop up so small like it was ground beef with over 75% of onion, a good thing I love onions. I had to give the credit on the chow fun, it was decent, but still not good. If this Resturant was in china town the wouldn't last more than a month. Nothing special, I will never come back.
Best Peking duck in Dallas! Service is awesome.. However this place does get packed.. I would suggest calling previous to going to see wait times...

I haven't found any other place with good peking duck in Dallas yet, and the duck is always pretty good here.  Be sure to pre-order it at least a day or two in advance, since it takes some time to prepare.  All of the other dishes I've tried here have been authentic and tasty, as well.  Come with a group if you'd like to eat family-style and try more dishes.  I'll definitely be back to try more of their menu items!

My star rating is all about the food and service.  This is a very casual joint in Plano that by the looks of things must be housed in an old pizza Hut. Packed in a random week night we were glad we made reservations.  If you want the Peking duck (and why wouldn't you! ?) Pre order this 24 hours in advance. .. the beggers chicken is 48 hours I think. We went for the duck and having had peking duck before at a top Beijing restaurant I wasn't expecting to be wowed.  But wowed I was.  They carve the little quacker table side and the pieces of duck skin with a thin layer of fat just melt in your mouth. They use most parts of the duck so you get to choose a fried rice duck dish with some parts or a soup with the bones. .. or you can ask for some of each. Everything was delicious. Some of the side dishes are well worth ordering too.  The eggplant dish was just phenomenal. If you want Peking duck I haven't found anywhere better in dfw (please message me if you have an alternative! )This is legit!
Love this place. Great service.  Duck carved at the table is fabulous. Roasted perfectly.All sides are good. Price is right.Limited parking however.Try it!  BYOB

I was really looking to this place after reading other yelper's reviews. I ordered the pot stickers as an app, and they were worse than the Mr. Panda ones I get at Costco. Too soggy, without that ever-so-slight crisp I really enjoy. The sauce was not quite sweet enough for my liking either. I ordered the Szechuan (sp?) chicken for the main course, and was once again let down. Very little chicken to vegetable ratio, and they use white meat, which tends to be too dry in many Asian dishes (IMHO). The service was good, and the BYOB aspect is always cool. I'm keeping it at two stars, because the price was reasonable, and maybe I didn't find "the right dish". A couple next to me ordered the roasted duck (carved tableside, I might add), and it looked delicious. I'd be willing to check it out again, but not after I try the 50,000 other restaurants in the greater DFW area.

Very small restaurant. Nice servers.  We came at 7:30. Got seat in 15mins.  Got the LAST duck (2 styles)! Yay!!! And it was only by chance because someone canceled their order.   Great crispy lean duck!! Yes! We picks the buns and it came out with enough Hoisin sauce and shredded green onions for the table! The only thing I can complain about the duck is it wasn't marinated in anything.  So without the hoisin sauce, there was no other flavor.  Our second style was sautéed, which did come out very flavorful! We heard the soup is kind of bland.  Sesame chicken... It was okay.  Lighter sweet flavor, a little different than what you are used to.  The chicken is very thin cut and a lot of breading to it. I don't think we would get this again. Whole tilapia - we didn't try it because the sauce it was doused in did not look appetizing.  Halfway to a very thick soup consistency. Our group was not impressed with it though saying the fish did not taste fresh and overcooked.   I would come back for the duck and the beggars chicken at another table looked very interesting.

This place is wonderful. My father and I frequent here often. Food is always delicious and the staff is very attentive. Down side is, being the location is rather small, in the evening the wait time can be long and the place becomes rather noisy.Food: Amazing. A++Atmosphere: Decent. Can become noisy when crowded.Service: Wonderful.I will definitely continue eating here and highly recommend others to try it out.

Peking Duck is superb - great service on a busy, busy Saturday night - we love our regular dishes: mango shrimp and water spinach - yum - depending on the friends we bring along, we order more dishes with their tastes in mind - it's also BYOB here - love Mr. Wok!!!

The Peking Duck is carved in front of you, which is interesting. You would think these presentations will only be offered in higher class restaurants. As for the taste itself, it was pretty good, but I still prefer Peking Duck at MyCanh. What I like most about the Peking duck here is that they offer you a choice - if you want to wrap your protein in the bun (which is what I prefer) or the mushu wrap (much like a tortilla wrap). I'll probably come back once in a while, but I'll head to MyCanh for the periodic Peking duck cravings.
Fantastic food and great service every time! We love this place! Plus, BYOB doesn't hurt!

Oh, Mr. Wok.  Oh, how I love you!  It had been quite some time before I had ventured back to reestablish this relationship.  It was Chinese New Year celebration week and on 2/21, I'd organized a group of friends to come try it.  It was the continuation of a beautiful friendship.I had done my duty, ordering the Peking duck 24 hours in advance.  I alerted my friends to the BYOB charm of the place.  We arrived at noon, our table having been reserved by Jack himself!  It was so crowded too and I was happy that my friends who arrived early were able to be seated.  The place is small and crowded due to the festivities.  We were able to savor our drinks, ordered appetizers to keep us busy and then enjoyed watching the two, huge beggar's chicken being rolled out to be smashed in by the guests who ordered them!  That looked fun.  A giant dish, with a puffy crust of bread was punched into by the mallets they give you with the meal.  Inside, a chicken that is stuffed with sticky rice and mushrooms, wrapped in foil to make it extra juicy and tender.  Oh, that is definitely on my list for next time!We ordered the wok seared edamame, which has a great flavor.  The crispy tofu that everyone tried- so fluffy and delicious paired with peanut sauce.  Vegetable fried rice that came with bean sprouts, vegetable chow fun noodles and a couple of appetizer samples- which had some fried stuff.  The steamed dumplings were delicious.  That kept us occupied until the duck arrived with Jack set to carve it like a master!  Oh, snap.  I am pretty sure I gave a brief set of instructions to the new acolytes!  First the bun, then hoisin, then duck, duck skin & scallions.  Roll that up and eat!  The carcass still had meat on it and we ordered that stir fried.  As the plate of duck was placed in the middle of the table, everyone dug in.  It became a race to see which of my duck loving friends could keep pace with me.  As everyone slowed down and I started in on my 4th roll up, I could tell my party was fat and happy!  We walked away with leftover Peking duck stir fry, fried rice and noodles.  For my party of 8, the tab came out to $17.xx and for the culinary feast we enjoyed, that is well worth it.  Somehow, I ended up with the leftovers in my fridge.  No worries, friends, they're all gone now- and yes, I shared with a couple of other friends!  All of it was so good and such a rare treat!  Until next time, Mr. Wok, I'll be dreaming of that delicious, buttery duck skin- and planning my next attack!

Food (***** out of *****); This is the best Peking Duck in Dallas. Unless you want to fly to China, you will not find a better Peking Duck. The skin is crispy, the fat underneath is soft and warm, and the meat is juicy. Yum! The duck could be seasoned with herbs and salted just a tad more, but that's just a minor nit pick. Their other dishes are good to ok, but the duck is stellar! I normally just order the duck. It's a big bird so if you're just 2 people dining, there's enough food in the duck dish to feed 2 people for several meals (take some home). The duck comes with Chinese tortillas or bread buns, green onions, sauce, and after you're done, they can use the bones to stir fry it or cook a soup with them. Their fried fish is good. Everything else is just ok. Ambience (** out of *****); Restroom is not very clean, but to be fair, it not disgusting, either. They really should put some of those blue disinfecting balls in the bowl and have some air fresheners in there. The restaurant is very tiny. However, you cannot fault someone's restaurant for being tiny, because it costs MONEY to pay rent. What most reviewers don't know is that on weeknights when business is slow, they still have to pay rent.Service (**** out of *****); Good service. The waiters had good teamwork. You can ask any of the waiters for assistance and nobody will turn you down because, "it's not my table." (I just hate that)Conclusion; Although the tally is 4 stars, I gave them an extra star due to superior value. The restaurant is BYOB so you're free to bring your own alcoholic drinks. I love Peking Duck with Tsingtao beer. Ain't nothin' better. It's a great deal. For $35 (not including tax and tips), you get enough food to feed two peeps for 2 to 3 meals. Yay!

Went here twice in two consecutive days. The first night, after coming on my friends request (she said she was craving peanut butter chicken. I shrugged it off as a white person thing), we arrived at 8, and their business was booming. We had to wait at the front for 10 awkward minutes before one of the 2 waiters even looked at us. They had an extensive menu, and my first thought was, how can they possibly cook so many things well?! They don't. I ordered the Sizzling Seafood Platter, which was absolutely disgusting. But my friends PB Chicken was to die for.  Second visit was with my bf. The crab porridge appetizer was tasty! We ordered the pecking duck, which is a 5 star over and over again. It honestly reminds me of the Beijing duck I eat back in my home country. The skilled waiters carve he duck in front of you! (If you order their bread chicken, they put on yet another good show!) The skin is so crispy, don't hesitate to add it in your wrap; the put it on the side, but it's not just garnish! For the second course that comes with this order, we had the stirfry option and it was very flavorful (duck soup isn't good). They didn't waste part of this animal, just like we do it in China! The patrons all seems very happy. But what I suggest for first timers, just order their most popular specials to be safe.

Fantastic!! Three Peking Ducks, plenty of appetizers, and great laughs with friends. With the duck leftovers we did two bones and a soup! Both were amazing! Mr. Wok, where the lazy Susan turns into the roulette of death when you over order!

Great food and great service!! Though it's very busy, our server, Allison, took great care of us. We ordered the salt n pepper calamari, potstickers, Bok choy n shiitake mushroom, and the famous Peking duck (remember to preorder this or else they won't have one for you). The bill come up to about $60, so cheap!! It was a pleasant surprise lol. All four of us were very full. This restaurant is small and intimate. Definitely recommend to reserve before going because it's small and they get packed pretty quick. They don't care about food presentation at all (hence its not really picture worthy). However, the flavoring really made up for it (isn't that what food is really about anyway?). The dishes were presented in their simplest form. As for the main dish (which is the Peking duck) is one of the best I've ever tasted. The skin is crispy and the meat is tender. They carve it right in front of you. Will definitely be back again.Merry Christmas everyone!

My family and I have been coming here for ten years and the food is consistently good every time. The Szechuan beef is excellent and the dish has tons of flavor without being too oily/greasy. Yummy food at a great price, they do get very busy so consider getting your food to go if you're in a hurry. Love this place
Absolutely amazing food. We have the Peking duck in the Beggars chicken and it was outstanding. I'd recommend this place to anybody and we've eaten everywhere.

I'm going to visit Mr Wok again this Friday for Birthday party.  This place is a GEM.  Best Authentic Peking Duck plate ever and it tastes heavenly.  Reservation is mandatory for ordering Peking duck because they roast it over night.  Place is pretty small so it gets really crowded fast.  I think after 7 pm during weekend, good luck finding a table if you don't make reservation.  Peking duck is about $35 and most people trying to get a table, order this to make sure they have a reserved seating.a master carver demonstrates carving a whole peking duck infront of you, that was a treat!  tastes so good!BYOB so you can bring your six packs or a wine if you preferhope you enjoy like we did and we will again

I really enjoyed our sit down experience. Normally I do pick up, but my husband wanted to go with me. Upon walking in, he commented how cozy it felt. We decided to eat there. Immediately were seated and had great service the whole time thanks to Allison! This place is BYOB. Awesome! Will remember for next time. The food was delicious. Mr. Wok came to check on us and it felt welcoming! We recommend this place for sure!

Make the reservation a day ahead for the Peking duck. Amazing table presentation of the duck. Get the steamed buns to enjoy that crispy duck skin!!Not sure what the soup after presentation is like but the stir-fry with the duck bones and remaining meat was so flavorful. The pot stickers are so good that I could have eaten a plate full. So full and no regrets!

I love Mr. Wok's Peking Duck. The skin is crispy and melts in your mouth. The meat part is tender and juicy - all without ducky smell, while keeping the flavor within. I had the duck to-go several times because of this, and have enjoyed them at home and friends' places. With that said, the service we had on the last time we visited (dine-in) was unpleasant. We had a reservation for 7:30 to serve my mentor's family and his mother who was visiting. The party arrived at 7:10 - with 4 kids all under age of 6 - as the weather was bad and we did not want to risk of being late. (If arrived late more than 15 minutes, then the restaurant reserves right to give up the table.)  We let them know we have arrived, who acknowledged  the reservation for 7:30. The people who were sitting at the table where we were assigned to were finished eating and already had their leftovers to-go, but they were sitting there until 7:32 - which was fine. Even after the table was cleaned, we were not able to sit for another 15 minutes. After we sat down, our appetizer did not come out for another 15 minutes. For 7:30 reservation, our meal started 35 minutes late. As I arrived, I asked if the meal could be ready at 7:30, as the kids are hungry, which they replied "yes". But that was not kept. Another thing was carving. I read so much of how nice to see duck carvings on the table side. As I had the ducks to-go before, I was really excited for this experience. Our first duck was carved behind us, which practically no one was able to watch without bending or twisting. I showed the lady a nice spot with no traffic and plenty of space, on the table, but she refused. She came to the empty spot for the second duck, thankfully, the party was able to see the carving and take pictures. The ducks were luke-warm, and soon turned cold. Asking for straws, fork, and/or napkins? Good luck, b/c it took us multiple requests and a long wait to get them on the table. I was really embarrased to treat my mentor and his family at this restaurant with the long wait, multiple requests on utensils, and luke-warm food. I still tip them plenty for the food, but not sure if I would visit the place again with the service I have experienced.

One of my favorite restaurants in Dallas/Fort Worth! I highly recommend ordering their Salt & Pepper Calamari and their Peking Duck! It is best to call in and make a reservation for the Peking Duck to ensure availability, since it is a hot commodity. Their Peking Duck, complete with either buns or pancakes of your choosing, is absolutely amazing. I especially love it since it is very reminiscent of my childhood. They bring it out to you freshly cooked and slice up the juicy and tender meat right in front of you! The service is also impeccable here. The entire staff and owners are friendly, sweet and highly accommodating! If you haven't tried Mr. Wok, you are really missing out!
First time to eat here. It's very good Chinese food try the orange chicken it's very tasty
This place has some of the best Chinese food I have been coming her for 18 yrs the owner jack knows my whole family, they are byob and make u feel like family love this place

I love Mr. Wok! I just come here for takeout for lunch or dinner but ever ytime I get something I am always satisfied and glad I came.  Their lunch menu is inexpensive and extensive.  They have traditional Chinese food that has all the great flavor and authenticity of a real Chinese kitchen---no mall food court bland food here.  I recommend the Mongolian beef or any of the shrimp dishes.  So glad this place is close to work!

Truly amazing Peking duck and crispy fried whole snapper. The Peking duck is huge and juicy. Also, the chef pumps air between the skin and meat of the duck before roasting it, thus allowing the skin to get super crispy and lean. Most of the fat simply drips off while the duck is being sliced at your table side. Our server recommended the whole snapper with black bean sauce. I haven't had fried whole fish this amazing since my trip to Hong Kong.  Presentation of the duck and snapper are excellent. Really impressive authentic Chinese food (except the fried rice which was not good)

They are known for their Peking Duck and Beggars Chicken which is a chicken makes inside a giant bread ball.  The bread ball is too hard to eat and is just for show b/c you have to crack it with a mini hammer. Peking duck usually needs to be ordered a day in advance but you may be lucky and be able To order same day since they make extras sometimes. Duck is the best thing: crispy and fresh and they carve it at your table. Small, hole in the wall place. U can eat the duck with steamed buns or the crepe like pancakes but I love both! "Other items on the menu like twiced cook pork and mapo tofu are standard and decent. Banana chocolate eggrolls are a nice sweet treat for dessert. I'd go back for more duck and crepes. Beggars chicken is good but more for show. Good for groups but it's a small place so reserve!

Read the reviews and stopped by. Sat down and were asked for drinks. We asked if they have mineral or sparkling water (our preference) = doesn't have any. Asked for bottled water = doesn't have any. Asked if their water was filtered. Waitress went back to ask and said no just tap water. We got up and left but not before telling them that they should have more options than sodas. They apologized which was decent. Sad in my opinion since I would have loved to try their food.

Mr. Wok is a Chinese restaurant in Plano that is known for an excellent Peking Duck dish they serve.  It's also located in a renovated Pizza Hut.  You'll find some other good dishes here but if you're going to only make one visit, order the Peking Duck.My Overall Rating - 3 Stars (Atmosphere, Service, Food, Return)Atmosphere - It's in a renovated Pizza Hut.  I know I said it already but there are implications.  First, it's a popular/busy spot so parking is limited.  Also, they try to squeeze in as many tables as possible that the result is there's very little room between tables/chairs.  On really busy nights there may be wait so make reservations and call in your Peking Duck order.   1/2 Star.Service - Our server was awesome.  I could tell that not only was he used to working with large groups but with tight spaces.  As dishes started coming out for our party of 10, he was able to expertly move, combine, and find spots to keep food going on the lazy Susan.  Add the fact the drinks remained full the whole time in the chaotic atmosphere leads to one finely skilled server.  1 Star.Food - This the third time I'm mentioning the Peking Duck.  They bring it to your table, cut/carve it up, and then serve it up with steamed buns or pancakes.  I preferred the thin pancakes but it's nice to have an option.  What's great is that there's no bone, it's hot & fresh, and is the best Peking Duck I've had in DFW.  Definitely the best dish they have....and the most memorable.  The rest of the dishes were forgettable, including the mango shrimp that I couldn't decide if I should have eaten it hot or cold.  Bottom line is that while the one dish they made was the best I had in DFW, I can't recall anything else I really liked.  But best in DFW does carry a lot of weight.  1 Star.Will I Return? - When they move to a bigger place.  I feel Mr. Wok needs to be moved to a new, bigger space.  The old Pizza Hut is actually cool, but it's not claustrophobic friendly.  The Peking Duck is outstanding and is a no brainer to order.  I guess even if they stay put I'll still be a huge fan of this signature dish.   1/2 Star.My Yelp Rating Scale (Sum of all parts):1 Star - Atmosphere - Is it a cool dive?  Perhaps an upscale place?  No matter the type, atmosphere plays a big part and I'll give a star if I like it or thinks it has great charm.1 Star - Service - You can have a great meal with bad service.  But that's also what can make a five star joint drop to four.  It's important to the dining experience that service is great and on point.2 Stars - Food - I'll award up to two stars for the food, since this is the main reason we dine out.  Sometimes the extra star is given for value, but it's really all about the food.1 Star - Will I come back? - If I know for a fact I'll return, I'll give this a star. A place has to make an impression for me to return. Each Category can be given up to 1 star except food (2 stars) because I consider all these categories important to the overall dining experience.  I will sum them up to provide my final Yelp score.

Customer service here deserves a 3. Called in ahead to make a reservation and we had to wait an extra 30 minutes. I had to order my food ahead for the group so that when the seat us, the food would be ready. Once we were seated, we got all our food right away. The peking duck came in a little later. I gave this restuarant a 4 just because of the duck. One of the best ive had because it wasnt greasy or fatty at all. Very lean and it came with the pancakes and bao. Overall, good chinese food for DFW.

Another great Peking duck experience at Mr. Wok. Well worth the long drive and 45-minute wait for the freshly roasted bird with the crispiest of skins.Bonus: 2nd course with the bones is included, either soup or stir-fried with pickled cabbage. Yum!Pro Tip: Remember to bring your favorite adult beverage as it is BYOB with no corkage fee...
