I was there for lunch to scope the place out before taking the whole family there to feast one weekend.  The friendly waitress seated me quickly.  I ordered the Sichuan shrimp lunch special and opted for Hot and Sour soup.  After tasting the first spoon of the soup, I detected slight bitterness, maybe some of the ingredients were burnt?   Then I guess the MSG started to kick in and made the soup tasted smoother.  The Sichuan shrimp came with very small shrimps, I don't know, 200 counts?  Put one in my mouth and a slight fishy odor hit my scent - shrimps were not fresh!  I tried to pick off the vegies but the sauce was too sweet.  I paid and left looking for something to eat.  Ended up getting double cheese burger for lunch :(  I wondered how can the same people who make great Peking ducks that people raved about, be cooking crappy food like this?  They must have different chef doing the ducks?  I have a friend who owns a restaurant in Richardson and he uses second string chef to cook during lunch.Place is located in the part of town that could use more rennovation.  Service was friendly and efficient.I will definite not come back to this place for lunch, but still on the fence about coming back for the Peking duck since it is spoken so highly by my friends.

This is a small restaurant and it can be a long wait depending on the time and day you go.  So far, the only thing I like about this place is their Peking duck with the white small buns and also a crispy tofu.  We had tried a few different items on the menu, but didn't like it.  The prices are reasonable and the services are friendly and fast.

First of all, we decided to try this place because of all the wonderful reviews.We made reservations for 7pm on a Saturday night. We weren't seated until close to 9pm.We were starving and the entire restaurant was packed to the gills and there wasn't even walking space. If someone called the Fire Department, they would have shut them down. It was so dangerous.When we finally got seated, it was another 30 minutes wait before anyone noticed that we hadn't been served. We tried to wave down serving staff, but it was just too packed.  It was like Black Friday shopping.Some folks, I guess regulars, helped themselves to plates and napkins.My first advice is unless you come for the Peking Duck, don't bother. Everything else is American Chinese. Go to your local Panda Express for their other dishes.The Peking Duck is very good.  Come here for that and don't come back for another 6 months because you will have a heart attack from all the fat and grease, if you have another one any sooner.A good sign of an authentic Chinese restaurant is by looking at the ratio of Asian diners vs non-Asian.  It was easily 80% non-Asian.I won't be coming back.
We tried had the Peking duck with buns, green beans, crispy tofu, fried tilapia and chicken wings. It was worth the drive from Fort Worth! A must try.

The Peking duck is one of the most amazing meals I've ever had. The meat is juicy and tender and balances perfectly with the scallions and hoisin sauce in their made-from-scratch pancakes. It's served in two courses, first as an entree, then as either a soup or stir fry. They split it for us and made both second courses. Both were amazing! The egg rolls are the best I've ever tasted and the wok seared edamame is a unique treat. Service is top notch, and the bill always seems like a bargain for the quality of the food and service.

Jack from Mr Wok does a great Job!  Really good Chinese food - probably some of the best that I have had in the DFW area.  We had a duck - it was soooo good - the stir fry that accompanied it was great as well.  I really like that the duck is served with the traditional pancake to wrap it up in and not that spongy thing other places use.  The eggplant and garlic - YUM - the mango shrimp- YUM - the Fried rice - YUM and the green beans with pork YUM!   Nothing but really good things to say.  The cuts on the veggies were consistent, which made everything cook the same, the skill used to slice the pork was spot on - just like its done in China.  The Duck presentation is excellent!    Make a reservation!! This place gets packed!  The service is spot on- the wait staff does an excellent job!  Its BYOB - so do just do it!  I really liked visiting with Jack, he took the time to come out and visit with several of the tables - this is not something that you see often.  Can't wait to go back!
This place is the best place I have found for Chinese Food in Plano.  Great food.

Favorite fast casual Chinese restaurant in DFW. Get the duck, sesame chicken, crispy tangy beef, or fried calamari! The owner Jack is very personable as well. He takes time to talk to each table and makes everyone feel valued.

Drove all the way out here to eat on recommendation of my cousin and his family. I agree with all the other reviewers...the Peking duck is AMAZEBALLS. Fresh and well marinated, cut at tableside. The skin is crispy and tasty, but not overcooked. The meat is flavorful and blends perfectly well with their freshly made plum sauce and cut scallion strips. The buns to wrap the Peking duck are soft, fresh and delightfully warm from the oven. I did not like the beggar's chicken as much as the duck, but it was tasty as well. The chicken is stewed in a giant bread bowl for 22 hours with sticky rice, giving the chicken meat a soft, melt-in-your-mouth almost bite and a sweet aftertaste from the rice. My uncle got the honors of cracking the bread bowl open too. We also ordered two vegetable dishes cooked with garlic sauce. The veggies were fresh and flavorful very well. Definitely go with some friends because the entrees are pretty big. The entrees are served family style. This place is delicious!

Great food and service. They really make the effort to accomodate since seating is really tight here. For those parties of 6 or more or those that preorder a Peking duck,you can make a reservation. Otherwise on a fri or sat be prepared to really wait unless you come in way before the rush...the one time I ordered a dish and not to my liking..they were most gracious in replacing it with something else. I always over order and glad to have leftovers to take home.  My only peeve is the tea pot...wish it was cleaned and shined..kind of greasy...and.  yes it is byob.
First visit was fantastic; friendly staff and Peking Duck was delicious. We will be back for sure!

I had the curry noodle, and my husband had the sesame chicken. My husband was more pleased that I was...mine was just greasy and had a weird after taste. Hard to explain.I will say most people were ordering the Peking Duck...majority of the place...but I would need to go back and try with another couple. If I do I will gladly remove this post and post better. But as of now....meh!Oh...and always ackward to enter and not know if its "wait to be seated" or "seat yourself"....and this was something that was a problem for others as well. Large photos of food are ok....but sign letting new people know what you expect in simple seating would be highly appreciated.

Unfortunately horrid- I've never spit out Chinese before now. I got sweet and sour chicken with fried rice- rice was hard and sauce for the chicken was awful. Chicken was the only remotely edible part and it was mostly breading.

Had an excellent meal tonight.  We were lucky enough to get duck (normally have to reserve at least a day in advance).  Also Mango Shrimp and my fav Spicy Chicken in Peanut Sauce.   Service is fast and friendly and food is consistently excellent.  We'be been coming here for at least 15 years.  Lots of regulars.  The table next to us ordered and impressive dish as well called Beggars Chicken...I think you have to call ahead a couple of days in advance  for that one too.  They don't take reservations for seating.  Don't deliver.  Do take phone orders for pickup.  Yummy to the nth degree.

Food is awesome. Really relaxing place. Try their noodle soups (ramen), its super filling and not too expensive. Owner is a really cool guy too. I'm still waiting to try the duck. I've seen it served a few times when I was there and I really want to try it.Friend had the coconut chicken. I tried a bit of it, really really good. Big portions too.Would totally go again!

After reading several reviews we had to try out this place.  It was a Friday night around 8:30 and I decided to call to see if they have any extra peking duck since you have to preorder a day in advance.  Luckily they had one left and we were on our way. The restaurant is located in an area you wouldn't expect a restaurant to be located.  The place is small yet intriguing.  When we arrived the parking lot was almost full (1 spot left) I thought to myself, we must be destined to come here.  When we got through the door we waited about 5 minutes.  The restaurant was packed but somehow there was one table for 2 available.  This can't be happening!   Our last yelp outing, we waited 2 hours.We orderedPeking Duck, Mango Shrimp, and the Han fried rice. The fried rice looked a little greesy but is was good. The Mango shrimp was also good but our favorite was the Peking duck.  As the owner carved the duck it looked  very lean and succulent.  The owner asked us if we have been here before and we said no.  He told us that we had the choice of a 2nd course (left over from the duck) of duck soup or stir fried duck (my favorite).  The said he will do both since this is our first time here. (very nice of him to do that). Both dishes were good. We liked that they put clear noodles in the soup.  Back to the peking duck... : ) We also liked that they offer both the buns and tortillas and they weren't cheap on the sauce and scallions (nub that!).  We were pleased with the duck but wish the meat was a little more tender.  By far the best Peking duck in the Dfw area.My only complaint is they serves warm sodas from a can. By the time I poured my drink into the glass the ice has melted and it tasted flat and watery.  This won't stop me from coming back.  I'll just order water.The service was great.  The owner and our waitress were really nice.  It's  very rare to find this type of service in an Asain restaurant.We look forward to ordering the chicken beggar (pre-order 2 days) next time.Thanks to all the Yelpers for making our dining experience such a blast!

Those giving rave reviews have obviously never tasted good Chinese food before. Had the mango shrimp which was edible but not spectacular. Someone needs to tell Mr. Wok dirty dishes should be taken to the kitchen not kept by the entrance. I question the health rating on this place.

Ok this is my favorite Chinese restaurant in DFW and as good as the ones in NYC Chinatown. Peking duck is a must it must be ordered a day before , everything was great, also love that's it is BYOB they will even open your bottle and supply wine glasses. Only problem is its not that big and gets crowded quickly, so get a reservation and get there early and you still may need to wait but can wait with a glass of wine.
Went there for the first time last night. Wow jammed pack with customers. Great food. We have appetizers, main course and everything was freshly made and wonderful.

Don't let the exterior fool you! It looks like an old Pizza Inn or something. With a lovingly hand written sign on the door that says "Entrance". It came highly recommended and it's BYOB, which is important to us, since we are in the wine business. I was skeptical, because we are regulars at First Chinese BBQ, which I think is killer! The interior is cute and cozy. It's a small place and the place was packed! On a Wednesday! NOTE TO SELF...MAKE A RESERVATION IF i'M COMING AFTER 7PM.We ordered crab Rangoon and the house cinnamon egg rolls. They were good but not mind bowing great. But the entrees were mind blowing delicious! A few that were note worthy were: orange peel chicken, crispy tangy beef, and Singapore noodles.They were all delicious! I highly recommend the crispy tangy beef. It was like a beefy pork rind in sweet and spicy sauce. Sooooo yummy.  But everywhere I looked, diner after diner ordered the Peking Duck! Except for the diners next to us who ordered a beautiful whole, fried, and sauced red snapper to share! Hell Yea! I'm definitely ordering that next time!And the Peking Duck!The service was great. Friendly and attentive.And the bill was a pleasant surprise. Definitely going back.

Been here about twice and loved it both times and since I am Asian, I think my reveiw ought to count for twice what the other "white people's" reviews are. But, thats just me.Ambience: Its an old Pizza Hut and you can tell they put a little bit of thought into the decor. It wasn't a let-put-up-some-pictures-of-the-mainland-and-call-it-a-day. There is a copious amount of red in the decoration but that's cool because they are asian. I personally expected a gold painted stone foo dog at my table with me. But I will settle for good food. Everything is clean. The bathrooms don't make me feel like I am going to come home with a STD. All good in my book.Food: Get the Peking Duck. You have to call a day in advance and they carve it at your table. I have had the leftovers done both ways: fried and in soup. And I have to say I prefer the soup because then you are are not picking up weird, unrecognizable duck parts hoping you are not eating something that you normally wouldn't touch with a nine-foot-pole let alone put in your mouth. I mean, I am just sayin'. You should eat everything family style and completely over order because everything here is good. I like their Eggplants (that taste like beef - not everything has to taste like chicken), their calamari for appetizers, their curry isn't bad. But why would you order curry at an chinese restaurant? Their noodles are pretty awesome.Service: Thankfully they are not a completely asian-fied restaurant which means their servers don't come by, throw the menus at you and go "whatchu want?". The owner came by to make sure everything was dandy. No complains on this front.Personally, if you want some chinese food, you can't really go wrong with Mr Wok's. They have been gently Americanized so they are stuff that you normally won't see at the normal chinese mom and pop places and the prices are reasonable. You should grab some friends and order up some duck.

Known for their crispy skin Peking duck but I also enjoy the fact that they bring out the duck and slice it super thin for you at table side. It's an experience! Other highlights include great service of friendly English speaking wait staff, clean place, fusion menu, and BYOB ( they have wine glasses, no corking fees, no drinking wine out of Chinese tea cups either) :)
2 dishes:Peking DuckMango  Shrimp.Hands down. We love this place!

I recently phoned in an order for some Mr Wok takeout, and I'm sad to say that the food was atrocious.  The service was pretty good, though.  Prompt and correct order taking, along with a quick follow-up when one of the noodle dishes was out.  Definitely can't do any better with customer support.  I just wish the food was just as good. Perhaps it was an off-night for the restaurant, but all of the food ordered (combination fried rice, pot stickers, chow fun, egg drop soup, sweet and sour chicken, etc.) seemed to be missing the following key characteristics: pleasant aroma, flavor, texture.  [I'll concede on the texture part, as this was take-out, and the containers usually don't keep crunchy noodles or fried foods crisp.]However, all of the food sampled had a strong pungent odor that smelled a bit like week-old chicken or dish cleaner.  The food tasted a bit consistent with the odor, and (while certain whiffs did remind my nose that this is Chinese food) made me a bit fearful that this sampling might run a number on my system.All the same, the search for a great Chinese restaurant in Plano keeps turning up some pretty poor results.  I have hopes that one day there'll be a restaurant which consistently delivers great quality Chinese food.

Make reservations and call in advance if you want Peking duck.  We were lucky and they happened to have a few extra and we were able to call in on a Friday night and still come and get the Peking duck.  You can also opt to get the steamed buns (like gua bao buns) instead of the thin pancakes but they want you to order that over the phone in advance as well--they almost got angry with us for not asking for the buns over the phone.  The duck is delicious--it's lean and crispy and tender.  The buns are great with them and they are very generous with the portions of green onions and sauce.  The Peking duck is given to you in two courses--one with the meat and the other to make use of the bones: either stir-fried or in soup.  We tried the stir-fry which is basically the bones with the rest of the meat not carved on fried with Chinese salty pickled vegetables and a bunch of soy sauce.  It's flavorful but it was way too salty for my liking.  I wouldn't recommend it and next time, we'd choose the soup.  For $32, a whole fresh duck in two courses is a steal.We also ordered the mango shrimp as recommended by the other Yelpers.  It was okay but I wouldn't order it again.  For $12 you get a good portion of mango and about 8 fried shrimp in a small crispy wonton shell.  Cool concept but not worth it.To finish off the meal, we shared one order of sauteed green beans (only $6) but they really only give you $6 worth. It was a tiny tiny portion.  Barely enough to share for four people.  They were flavorful though...definitely not skimping on the garlic!  We also got the beef chow foon--pretty standard--but, we needed something to feed the toddler!The food is pretty standard except for, of course, the Peking duck.  The Beggar's Chicken also looks extremely intriguing and the smells coming from the one ordered across the room gave me some food envy.  I definitely want to try it next time I'm in Dallas.  But, they do require 48-hour notice.  (Pretty much, when you call to make a reservation, they want you to be able to order your entire meal. ;) )The space is crowded and not designed for the claustrophobic.  The atmosphere is hectic: huge parties crowd around round tables in the center, drinking wine (the restaurant is BYOB) and laughing, and then lots of parties of 2 to 4 lining the walls in booths designed to fit 1.5 people. Literally.  The restaurant is a bit dirty too--the windows by each of the booth tables have piles of dust that have seemed to accumulate over years of time and the curtains are distracting and dusty as well.  Definitely needs some more attention to detail in the cleaning department.
This place is awesome. Great variety of dishes and have had a great meal every time. Not greasy like other places and not too pricey. Great authentic Asian food!

This place was ok. It failed a couple of my benchmarks that typically indicate a good Asian establishment (they accept credit cards, had no visible Buda statue at the front door and I also saw mostly Americans patrons). But the food was good. American-Asian I would call it, not Asian-Asian which is my typical preference.We followed the Yelp suggestions and had the Tangy/spicy beef. Not overly breaded and had crisp, fresh veggies.I was disappointed, however, they didn't have any thai peppers to make my dish spicy...I'm still trying to figure that one out...but it was a decent meal on the whole. One of the members of our party got the lettuce wraps and reported much satisfaction.The menu was extensive, lots to pick from.The service was fast and the server was friendly enough. She even came back to refill our teas twice, before it was essential. We plan on going back cause the Peking Duck looked AWESOME!! Something that needs to be called ahead.As I sat there, I re-read the Yelp reviews and I didn't see any black stuff coming out of the air returns. I didn't see any indication of an unclean establishment either.

Food quality: Food quality is pretty good. I sampled mostly every type of dish (our table was a foodie crowd) from rices, soups, noodles, entrees, appetizers, salads and signature dishes. Rice dishes are colorful and contain many ingredients, but the rice grain is bland and not flavorful, a little soy sauce easily fixes this. The lo-mein had very thick noodles and the dish was a tad on the greasy side, but still flavorful. The "orange chicken" style entree was good, although the sauce was a bit too sweet and the breading (batter) on the chicken is too thick. The vegetable dishes I tried were all super good and fresh and looked spectacular. My table ordered the Peking Duck, the apparent "hype" plate of the restaurant and it did not fulfill my expectations. I was really looking forward to the duck, given the apparent hype around the plate and all the reviews that comment on how good it is, but it really is not that spectacular. Do not get me wrong, the dish is pretty good, but the amount of meat that the duck gives when carved is very little and some skin flakes are crunchy, others are soggy and too greasy. We chose to have our duck leftovers done in a soup (you can choose between soup or stir-fry) and the soup was very greasy, hard to eat (sifting through bones) and lacked substance. The table carving aspect of the dish has so much potential, but the way they carved it for us was neither impressive nor fun.Food presentation: Food presentation is pretty. What you expect from any good, Chinese restaurant. The style of presentation is communal, so plates are big and meant to share.Appearance of restaurant: Restaurant is a definite "hole in the wall" but the food quality is way above their looks. It has a nice comfy, authentic feel to it. It can get a bit crowded though on busy nights. Cleanliness can be greatly improved (small details and not overall hygiene).Service: Service is good. Nothing too spectacular. I do not have any complaints or praises.Value: This is where this place absolutely rocks. This is definitely a place to go with a small group. Expect to pay less than $15 per person to literally stuff your face with delicious and authentic food.In general: This is a pretty neat place to go with a small group to try authentic Chinese food. Value is amazingly good and the food will not disappoint. Sure, they could improve some things, but you will leave satisfied when you take into consideration the whole experience and not some minor details that realistically speaking restaurants of this caliber are not expected to fulfill.Note: This review is based on my years of professional experience in the food and restaurant business and reflects my personal opinion.

Tried this place after seeing it being rated among D Magazine's Top 100 for 2013. I seriously doubt D Magazine's competency now after a lunch trip here.As other reviewers before have written, the place is a flashier version of Panda Express. The food is Americanized to the core, in flavor and spice. Don't expect anything authentic here. The Szechwan Peppercorn Chicken was bland, spice-less (after ordering extra spicy) and flavorless. The accompanying cup of fried rice was worse: dry & stale.I am not a Chinese but have eaten better authentic Chinese food around.

I can't say much for other dishes but the peking duck here is awesome! I went to Mr. Wok with my friend for a lunch date and we decided, why not get peking duck?! The presentation was great, the waitress brought the whole duck out and carved it in front of us, and then they used what was left to make a soup. Honestly, the soup was a bit bland and I didn't care too much for it but the buns and duck were MMM delish!

Ate here this weekend with the hubby on the recommendation of a non-yelper friend whose food advice I trust :)  It had never particularly stood out on Yelp to me before but they deserve some more lovin'!We were actually on our way to try out Lion City when we remembered this place--I called to see if they had any extra Peking ducks available and even though they were pretty busy, they were able to accomodate us and put us on the list (even though reservations are for 6 people + according the sign we saw when we arrived).  The girl on the phone warned us it would be 15-20 minutes wait, but we didn't mind since we hadn't even thought enough ahead to reserve a duck!  We were seated in about 10 minutes, and got straight to the duck-ordering.  Service from everyone we interacted with was very friendly, and we especially liked that it's the owner who carves the duck tableside for you and makes conversation.  Now I have to say I am somewhat spoiled because the first time I had Peking Duck was on our honeymoon--we went to China and while in Beijing we went to the place that invented it.  Now THAT was an amazing meal.  I can't say Mr. Wok (or any other place we've tried since) quite measures up but I really liked it and we'll definitely be back to get it again.  And I will also say it was better than the supposed best place in Houston Chinatown (which is generally superior to the places in Dallas Chinatown).  The duck carved for us was fairly lean but very juicy.  Quite a bit of it was left on the bones, but it worked out well because we decided to try the stir-fry of the remaining duck pieces/bones instead of the soup for the second course because we had never tried it that way before.   The stir fry wasn't as tasty as the traditional duck preparation, but it was interesting and we were glad we tried it.  I will also second whoever else I saw commented that the crepes were basically tortillas, which detracts from the experience just a tad, but I think you can order steamed buns instead so we'll check that out next time.   The skin was nice and crispy but it wasn't as razor thin as it should be and still had a kinda thick layer of fat underneath.  Still tasted delicious but wasn't as crispy that way.  My only REAL complaint about the experience was that I had been vacillating back and forth about whether I wanted to splurge on dessert and had finally gotten pumped up about the fried banana eggrolls but our waiter brought the check without asking if we wanted anything else.  I know dessert is not typical in traditional Chinese restaurants and I'm sure I could have asked for it, but I took it as a sign that I didn't need the dessert, especially after 2 weeks of a food-filled vacation.  I'll get it next time :)So yeah...basically...go here.  We will actually call ahead next time because we want to try out the Beggar's chicken, and they request 2 days notice for that one.

I have mixed feelings about this place.  The first few times we came, we really liked it.  But the last time we were there for Chinese New Year, it was a horrible night for both the restaurant and us.  They normally do not take reservations for 2 but since I was pre-ordering a lot of food, they accommodated us.  The place was packed and one table was complaining that they have been there for 2 hours and still haven't gotten all their food. So we were forewarn that it was going to be a long night. It did take 2 hours to finish our meal also. The waiter was very sorry each time he came by, we were like no problem.  I had pre-ordered the lobsters.  They were expensive and not good.  I was very disappointed.  They spilled HOT soup on us accidentally. Only got an apology, did not get comp or offer to dry clean our clothes.On other occasions, we had their peking duck and they were good. You have to pre-order and if you want steam buns, make sure you tell them when you call. The owner explained to us that they are specially flown in from NY and very lean.  The Beggar chicken was difficult to eat.  We didn't know we had to stir the dish well.  We ate from top down and it did not have much flavor at the top.  The family style tofu was really good, but it seems it is inconsistent.  Another time we came for the tofu and it was totally different than before.  The pork belly with preserved veg was good.  The place is very small.  It is best to go when they are not busy or holiday time.  From the outside, it looks like it used to be a pizza place.  Anyways you come here for the food, not the atmosphere.

Whole Snapper - do yourself a favor and try it next time, the sauce concoction was mind boggling-ly good! The chef here is a genius, can't wait to try their Peking duck - this place is a hidden find, love their ambience too.

Good decent Chinese good.  A tad greasy, but that's Chinese for ya.  It's the reason why my face is always oily...damn me for the things I eat! Didn't get a chance to order their special Peking duck but will def be back to get my grub on!

Other than the Peking duck and some appetizers i didn't really eat anything else here and I have been here 3 times so far. The Peking duck itself is enough to make me want to come back again and again. :) It is really delicious. You can get either tortillas or steamed buns with the duck but personally  I think steamed buns is a better choice. I would advise to call them in advance for the duck.  It's a great place for big groups of people. The customer service is great and don't forget its a BYOB.

We had a reservation at 12pm but we wait for another 1 hour and 15 mins to get our table. The lady sliced 80% of the duck to the table cloth and pick them up to the plate. When we  asked her to be careful, she stopped slicing and put the half empty plate to our table. We though the left duck will be stired fried and served us anyway but we were wrong. It came again with half empty plate for stir fried. How we know it? Everyone ordered duck that day and we have eyes. Service is awful there. I will not go.
Love this place. Great food great service and it's byob. Jack the owner is always  friendly  and cooks a great duck.
The Peking duck is simply incredible. Haven't had the opportunity to try any other dishes, but definitely worth the trip.....
Bland flavors. Woo point try again,  prefer to go to Psnda's to get something similar but with better taste . So go figure.

Guys...this place a diamond in the rough! Had my bday here with a party of 15. It was a first time for all of them and they ALL walked out impressed!Peking Duck (request the buns....it taste better)Mango ChickenBeggars ChickenThose are a definite must. Believe Jack's the owner. Pretty nice guy....even took a shot with us!BYOB as well

Awful!  I don't think I've ever eaten such bland Chinese before.  Orange chicken not orangy nor spicy,  just a sweet ish generic taste with no depth.  Bell pepper beef,  no taste at all.  Lo mein, bland and oily. No taste no taste no taste.  Fried Rice tasted kind of burned.  How can you screw up fried rice? ?? Had great expectations about this place.  Alas,  no luck.  Not coming back.  Ever.

Awesome food!  Wait can be long but that's probably due to their great food.  Loved the Peking duck.  Try to get the guy to carve it instead of the lady.  The guy seemed to be much more skilled.  Everything we tried was good or great.  Definitely go for the Peking duck.  Make sure you call ahead since it's very popular.

I've only been there twice for lunch with a group of folks and both times it was specifically for Peking Duck. But it was phenomenal. Each time I sort of wished we had left a few of them at the office so I could have a bigger portion. We ordered the bok choy as a side dish and it was great too. Attentive, professional service.

I've been to Mr Wok a number of times in the past several months; most recently with my brother and girl friend over the holidays. I wanted to go to a place that was not stuffy, and was fun, as well as a great dining experience. To date, Mr Wok has not let me down, and all of the people that I've taken rave about the food, staff, and owers.Mr Wok has always been a great place to go with hordes of people. Of course I love BYOB venues, where I can bring lots of wine. I have a more detailed review on my blog, danesemeats.com/?p=468, but suffice it to say, I have always enjoyed most everything I've eaten there.

Don't let the building turn you away. It's a hole in the wall for sure buy I was surprised by this place! The food is really good, and you get a ton for what you pay. It's really hard to find good egg foo young, but this place has it! We ordered food to go and it was ready in 15 minutes! Try the egg foo young and the combination lo mein, delish! Pork egg rolls are good and the crab Rangoon were fried to perfection. Definitely will be ordering from here again.

Yelper's Please Listen: This Place Sucks!!! I'm not a hater either.  Drove from Dallas to Plano to check this place out and what a horrible decision.  The duck was bland. I agree with everyone the duck is hot and fresh but it's flavorless. C'mon people 5 to 4 stars. The Chinese food is just as bad as the duck. I rather eat mall Chinese food. One waiter and one cashier = slow service! You will thank me later.

Despite all the good review for their Peking duck, I was disappointed after my first and most likely ONLY visit.  Maybe I have high expectation for my favor dish, the Peking duck, since I did grow up in Beijing and weekly Peking duck is a norm for me.  If you never tasted authentic Peking duck, then the duck here IS pretty good.  For people out there who are seeking the real Peking duck, you probably will be disappointed like me.  If you really want to taste some pretty good Peking duck without going to China, in Houston there is a restaurant at the corner of Gessner and hwy 95, call Peking Cuisine (go figure).  Ducks there is very close to true Peking duck, sometimes order ahead is preferred.  My last visit, I think the dish was $35, which came with duck and soup.  Mr. Wok's duck soup is just so wrong.  Soup supposes to be white color (a very long cooking process that turns a clear soup to white soup).  Here is what a true Peking duck should be like (if you don't agree with me, then maybe you shouldn't try the Houston place).1. Traditional Peking ducks are very fatty, dripped with oil once it is cooked.  That is only because the methodology raising the ducks is very different.  Those ducks in China are called stuffed duck.  Each and everyday, instead of self feeding, people actually grab the ducks by the head and push a tube filled with food into the duck mouth and force the food down, making the duck very fat.  Now days, the fat ducks are not less popular, so leaner ducks are an option on the menu.  2. The wrapper should be paper thin, because its only purpose is to hold the duck, the sauce and the onion.  Steam bun or tortillas is actually not ideal.  Steamed bun is only preferred by southern and I never saw eating ducks like that until I come to America.  I use tortillas at home only because I don't know how to make paper thin wrappers.  Both over powering the taste of the duck.  The Houston restaurant has good wrapper.3. The black sauce should be sweet and the onion is typically white part only.  Both are used to cover or overcome the greasiness of the duck.

Full disclosure alert. I was taken here by my friend Dave Gilbert, ex of Luqa and Lazare and fellow cooking conspirator. He knows the owners and suggested that I join him one evening for Peking Duck.It was damn good. The skin was perfect. The pancakes were a bit of a let down, though. They actually seemed more like tortillas than delicate pancakes.We, of course, had the soup made from the duck bones at the end - delicious too. terrific spicy eggplant, really good fish/tofu. rice bowls and I could have been in HK.The place doesn't have a license, so green tea was the drink of choice.As one might imagine, the service was impeccable, and the owner spent considerable time visiting - and even though Dave is a good friend of his, I didn't feel in the least left out.Great stuff.Oh if you are going to order the Peking Duck, do it a day or so in advance. It takes a while to make one of those suckers.

I wasnt expecting to eat much because we had just had tokyo one for lunch, but as the food kept coming, I really couldnt stop. They boast of an updated interpretation of traditional chinese food, and they really do satisfy the taste buds of chinese-food purists like my parents. Peking duck- They carve a whole duck in front of your table. The skin is crispy and the duck is juicy. It comes with all the traditional condiments except their wrap is actually flour tortillas. Its definitely worth the $30 and its definitely a highlight.Mango shrimp- The shrimp and mango sit inside a crispy wonton bowl. There wasnt enough shrimp but the mango pieces made up for it. They were sweet, fresh, and was a good counterpart to the creamy sauce. Chicken soup- I think this is another one you have to order in advance and I'm not sure if its even on the menu. It comes in a big clay pot and they simmer the chicken for so long that the soup becomes milky. There are bits of ham for more flavor and lotus "nuts"?. There were 6 of us and we still brought home 2 soup to-go containers full so this feeds a lot. The flavor of the soup was so robust and hearty. We usually dont eat very salty foods at home, so we asked for a cup of hot water to dilute. The waitress came back with the cup and also took a little sample back for the chef to taste so you definitely know they are really concerned about customer satisfaction and serious about controlling the quality of their food. I was really impressed!Do not be deterred by the pizza hut ambiance!!!

Vegetarians and vegans rejoice! There are so many choices on the menu, you'll have to take your time perusing them all.The peanut sauce that comes with the crispy tofu is good enough to involve espionage to figure out the recipe.A delightful establishment suitable for a quick lunch or a fancy dinner.

Poor service (crammed parties of 8 and another of 7 with reservations) into side booths with a small end table despite 2 large round tables being available. One hour later a party of 7 (5 adults and 2 small kids - similar composition as the other parties) was placed in one of the large round tables. When asked, the usher replied "I don't assign the tables". For large parties, the table remains crowded with empty platters as the service personnels do not automatically clear them away. Service personnels do not refill empty water glasses. Overall one star for poor service.Setting is a converted ex-Pizza Hut building. Minimal decor inside and tables are crowded together. Overall one and a half stars for below average setting/decor.The Peking duck is on par with one of the street side vendors in Flushing, NY. Other dishes tried (mango shrimp, fried whole fish, tofu with fish, and shrimp noodle) are on par with the cheaper restaurants in Los Angeles, CA. Not on par with the better restaurants in the Orient, New York, or California. Overall three star for food quality (average).

Peking duck!!!My family loves this place.Awesome service and food. Peking duck slicing & beggar's chicken service is somewhat of a show case and highly recommend bringing any visitors from out of town for a dining experience.Be sure to make reservations at least a day or two ahead as it says here for peking duck and beggar's chicken.Mango shrimp is awesome too.

Mr. Wok is a gem in East Plano.  Must try the Peking duck (order a day in advance to ensure you get one) and mango shrimp.  Their duck doesn't have a thick layer of fat like other Chinese restaurants.  I also like lettuce cool wraps, cold noodles, general's chicken, calamari, edamame.  Everything is good on their menu.  Satisfies both authentic and westernized Chinese/Japanese dishes.  Prices are very reasonable.  BYOB.  Great service.  Worth a try!

Definitely a word of mouth sort of place. It's located in a somewhat run-down area in east Plano, and other then the parking lot being full on the weekend, you would never guess that this Chinese restaurant is one of the best in DFW.Like the other reviewers say, the Peking Duck, Beggars Chicken, and Mango Shrimp are excellent. Everything else we ordered was good but not exceptional.The service at many Chinese restaurants can be terrible when busy due to being understaffed. However, I counted 7 employees on our visit to Mr. Wok on a very crowded Friday night which is a lot considering this place is so tiny. The four servers were great. Our party of 10 (along with two other large parties) kept them quite busy but they were very helpful and happy to make us feel at home. The owner is also a very cheerful, social guy who frequently talked to the diners to make sure everything was great. You can really tell that the workers here are very eager to satisfy their customers.And it's BYOB, so bring your friends and family along with a bottle or ten of spirits!

Found Mr. Wok online and decided to go. Tried to make reservations for 2 but unless ordering Peking Duck, Beggers Chicken, or have a party of at lest 6 reservations not possible. Took a chance and went anyway and no tables available so the staff brought in a table for us. Mr Wok seems to be king of Peking Duck as we saw at least 8 served in the hour we were there. We ordered tangy crispy beef and shrimp in garlic and sweet chili and both were amazing. Staff was great and attentive. Highly recommend.

Great People .... Great food.... and BYOB!  My typical order.....Edaname....Peking Duck... (pre-ordered) Salt and Pepper Squid...All 3 are great and plenty for a family of 4.Jack takes pride in his family history of great food and his wife helps take care of customer service as well.  Lets put it this way.  We drive out from Arlington to Plano to eat duck.  Enuf said.

My family and I love this place! But there are some secrets here that i am going to share with you, bc I love you. There are 3 things on the menu that you have to order 24 hours in advance: 1. Beggars Chicken- the presentation for this dish is unbelievable, i have never seen anything like it. This is a chicken that is wrapped in banana leaves and stuffed with 5 spice sticky rice and then covered in a dough and cooked for a whole day to preserve the flavor. The whole restaurant stops to watch as a huge ( like 20 pound) mound of dough is brought out to the table. The servers will let the people at the table attempt to crack the dough. After cutting open the dough and unwrapping the banana leaves, the chicken is finally presented. It is moist and flavorful. This is not my favorite dish, personally, I am not a fan of 5 spice. 2. Peking Duck- this too had to be ordered a day in advance, but they usually have some extras on the weekend. They start roasting the duck as soon as you get there and then they bring it out and carve it right at your table. It is served with "pancakes", scallion strips, and plum sauce. Amazing. You can then choose to have a soup made with the bones or a stir fry. The stir fry is the way to go. 3. Red Snapper- again, call ahead. I haven't had this one yet, I will def get it next time. More to come on that. The price is right, the staff is friendly, and the owner carves your duck or chicken at your table. I love me some Mr. Wok!!!!
service was good. I thought the yaki soba sounded good the waitress said it was and she was right.  a nice place and I am picky

I've had the pleasure of eating at Mr. Wok twice now and both times have been great.  For starters, the staff has always been friendly, welcoming, and attentive.The food selection at Mr. Wok is extensive.  They have a host of typical Chinese dishes as well as a few house specialties that you likely won't find anywhere else.  The Peking duck is very good and reasonably priced, though you have to plan in advance and order 1 day ahead.  I would have to recommend the wok-seared edamame each time you go -- it's inexpensive and absolutely incredible.  Other dishes I've tried are also very good, but these have stood apart from the rest.It's nice to find an independently owned stand-out restaurant in a sea of wannabes.  Give Mr. Wok a shot if you're looking for great Chinese food in a friendly, casual environment.  And it's BYOB, which helps keep the cost down if you plan to drink.

Mr. Wok has become my family's new favorite go-to place for Peking Duck.  (I believe my parents go AT LEAST once a month)  My Mom was a little disappointed that Jack (the owner) forgot who they were as they were frequent visitors, but they were still glad he was there as they claim he is the best person to have for slicing up the duck!   We ordered the preserved vegetable beef (my mouth is still watering), the tofu & salted fish (okay) and the Kung Pao Squid (good, but my parents thought it tasted more "western" than asian)  The REAL reason they come is for the duck!  (you need to call in advance to make sure they have it and to reserve your own!) The peking duck is delicious!!!  They slice it thin and the skin is so crispy and full of flavor!  You eat it with hoisin sauce, tons of thin flour 'tortillas' and spring onions.  Mmmmmm....  The best part comes afterwards where you have the choice of eating the remainder of the duck in soup or stir fried with even more preserved vegetables, garlic and spices!  (we chose the latter)  The waitstaff is incredibly friendly and attentive and Jack is quite personable as well.  (my Mother adores him!)  The atmosphere is somewhat asian (I have a suspicion that it may have been a pizza hut in its former life) but still comfortable.  I'll definitely be back with parents and friends for more Peking Duck!!!

Long wait but the food is worth it!  I only get the Peking Duck here since it's the best in Dallas.  It can get a little noisy and crowded at times but once you take the first bite, nothing else matters.  I make my own special sauce that compliments the duck and bring it with me along with some beers and I'm set!!

This place sucks. Ordered tonkotsu ramen and mabo ramen. Not good. It's insulting that they can make this and call it tonkotsu broth flavor. Also ordered the gyoza, as a starter as stated in the menu, it came out last after we finished the ramen. The bill even came before the gyoza. Please do yourself a favor and don't come here.reply to jack:If its considered Yokohama-style, then why don't you write Yokohama-style and not tonkotsu.  FYI: it's pretty important.  I don't think a french restaurant would write "foie gras" and give customers a plate of bullshit.  If your ramen noodles are fresh, then why is it imported from Japan.  I think fresh usually means its made by hand for daily use. And thanks for apologizing for the sh*tty service for the gyoza. HIGH FIVE!

Mr Wok has an impressive menu of various Asian dishes.  This isn't a Chinese food restaurant, it's an Asian bistro, with many Asian countries represented on the menu.  My favorite is the Cha Han, a delicious, addicting rice dish.  My wife orders it every time. They don't serve alcohol, but you can bring your own.  Mr Wok doesn't have high turnover amongst the wait staff, so they are educated regarding the menu, if you have questions.  I'd suggest this bistro to anyone who appreciates quality Asian food, and people whom like to try new things.

I am writing this review to comment on their policy for reservations.  Unless you have a party of six or more or you order their specials Peking duck or beggar's chicken, you will not be able to make a reservation. So if you have a small group and you don't want to eat the specials then don't bother coming during peak hours.   We went here on a Saturday night for two without reservation and we saw all parties without reservation basically left.  One regular customer even confirm the difficulty of getting a table here.  But we thought we could tough it out as we already drove thirty miles to get to this restaurant.  After a forty five minutes wait, we were told that our table was getting cleaned.   But then once it was ready, they gave it to a party of six with reservation, and all these people were squeezed into a booth designed for four.   While the food did look good, we thought their reservation system absolutely sucked.  They should do a first come first serve or take reservations for all.  There are plenty of other authentic Chinese food in Richardson so won't bother to go back.

Introduced Mr. Wok to yet another set of friends and once again it was a huge hit.  Peking duck was delicious as usual, but also fabulous tonight was the whole friend snapper and the Cantonese crispy noodles.

If you like Peking duck, then you'll love Mr Wok!  Being originally from Houston where you can readily get bonafide Peking duck, I was skeptical about trying this place out.  I'm glad I did though because it didn't disappoint. They carved the duck in front of us and then gave us a choice of stir frying the meaty bones or making soup with them (do the stir fry, it's pretty darn good).  Legit establishment with a very friendly staff in a cozy atmosphere.

So after hearing about this place and read the reviews, I decided to give it a try.  What a disappointment!  The Peking duck is very bland. Tasted more like boiled duck.  The tangy beef was way too saucy and not even crispy like the description.   Don't know whether because they are short on staff but service is super slow.  I would not recommend this place.  If you like Peking duck, go try tasty china in garland, much better!!!

I have to admit that I was a bit surprised . Walking up to the restaurant , it looked like an old run-down Pizza Hut .  And the parking lot is horrendous .  And inside it looks like a hole-in-the-wall , but once the food came out I was amazed .  We shared three orders of Peking duck ( which you have to pre-order 24-hour in advanced ), 2 orders of mango shrimp , beggars chicken  and lots more .  What's also great is that it's BYOB !  I was a bit surprised at the appetizer sampler .  The appetizers looked like something you would find at any fast food Chinese restaurant .  But overall I liked this place a lot .  Definitely something I would bring my parent to !

I love Peking Duck and this restaurant in Dallas is the closest we've come to find that offers authentic PD style ducks in north Texas.  Most of the other Chinese restaurants hasn't come close here at all but Mr Wok nailed it for us after years of searching.  After the duck is stripped of meat, you get a choice of either soup or stirfry from the leftover bones - nothing wasted.  I prefer the stir fry bones just so I can chew on the leftover bones.  We'd give it five stars if it's just the ducks but unfortunately other dishes kind of miss the mark.  If you want Peking duck then this is it - five quacks.  Other dishes are meh (tried the fish and the beggar's chicken and a couple others, passable but nothing great that stood out).  You do have to plan for the duck and order and reserve your seat a day in advance.  Oh and bring a good bottle of wine as it's BYOB.

The pecking duck and beggars chicken is the best their. The pecking duck is the first course and then you get an option of soup and something else with. The beggars chicken is magnificent but you have to order it 3 days before!!

Had dinner with the family tonight - tried both their Peking Duck and Beggar's chicken after all the raves from family/friends.I was a bit underwhelmed (maybe i was oversold and had high expectations).  The Peking Duck was good - crispy skin and not fatty!  The Beggar's chicken was a bit of a disappointment.  The flavor was a bit too herbal and the chicken seemed overcooked.Had a few other dishes:  mango shrimp - nice pieces of mangos and good flavor;  eggplant with garlic - ok..I guess you can't go wrong with eggplant;  pork with tofu & jalepenos and crispy tangy beef - forgettable.

Being from NYC,  I am used to great Chinese food.  Unfortunately this place is not one of them.  The noodle soup was utterly disgusting - soggy noodles and soup with absolutely no flavor. My wife is Japanese and even she couldn't stomach not than 2 bites.  Also tried the Moo Shu pork which was not good.  The only OK dish was the Chinese green vegetables.Trust me,  anyone that knows real food from the coasts will want your money back.  Come if you want to be ripped off.

One peking duck served 12 of us, and we ordered 3 of them.  I ate 5 servings myself.  My wife told me just because everyone else doesn't eat at lightning speed like me, doesn't mean they aren't planning to eat more.  Hey, you snooze, you lose.  Best peking duck and BYOB.  We will be back.

Dallas's best peking duck.  While the peking duck is awesome, everything does not seem to be authentic Chinese.  Kinda weird the the peking duck is made authentically but not the other dishes I've tried.  But I have to say I have only tried about five other dishes.  I have tried what seems to be the second best dish there which appears to be the chicken in this big whote enclosure that they let you smash.  The Peking Duck alone makes it 4 star if you love peking duck!!!

Second visit to-go this time.  My son had a hankering for ramen and he wanted to try the miso ramen.  Soup is deconstructed to-go and you get to put it together when you get home.  All ingridients were very fresh.  Noodles were excellent, my boy gave it a 7 out of ten - way better than deep-fried grocery store purchased noodles. Fried banana spring rolls were a hit again...we'll be back

Quite inexpensive for a place I didn't think was all that great.  It's a little better than your run of the mill chinese joint pushing General Tso's chicken, but not worth the extra imho.  Try a Vietnamese joint or something more interesting next time you want Asian, there's plenty around (surprisingly cosmopolitan) Greater Dallas.

I have eaten here 3 times.  I really wanted to like it because it is a mom and pop place not a chain and it is close to my house.  The food is ok, the service is ok, but the place is DIRTY!  They really need to remodel - there is filth everywhere.  Don't look at the air vents in the ceiling - there is black stuff hanging out of them.  The bathroom fixtures have dirt embedded in the grout and caulk.  It is too dirty to clean - just need to paint, tear out the fixtures, and start over.

I love the Duck!  It's not like most places where it comes with a thick layer of fat below the skin.  They cook it a special way so that the fat is melted off during the process, leaving a crispy skin and juicy meat!  I really enjoyed eating it with the sticky buns and making mini duck sandwiches out of them!  But definitely order the buns first!  It takes a while for them to bring it out.  They will ask you how you would like the leftover bones cooked after they finish carving it.  You can either get them stir fried or made into soup.  I've only tried the stir fry so far and was very happy with my choice.  It makes great leftovers as well!  We also ordered the Mango Shrimp which was ok.  I thought it was a bit too sweet but it was still tasty.  I would recommend trying to go with a group of 3 or more if you get the Duck or Beggar's Chicken.  It's a lot of food.  If not, go anyways and take leftovers home with you!!

Never write reviews, but this place is a little gem that is mainly known through word of mouth so wanted to share.   Was not a Peking duck fan until a friend insisted I try it here.  I've since tried duck all over town and hands down, Mr. Wok is the best.  Golden crispy skin, no fat, and succulent meat carved tableside.  Be sure to pre-order duck or you won't get any. It's a fun, lively, casual little place in an old Pizza Hut building.  Nothing fancy, just really good food.  Its been a big hit with all the friends and family we've brought too.  Service is friendly and personal -- you feel like family.  BYOB so bring your favorite booze.

If you want the freshest peking duck.. you gotta come here... you wanna have a little fun.. you gotta get the beggars chicken.  the food is superb. You get a fresh duck carved in front of you, then either stir fried or made into a soup.  The mango shrimp is to die for! All in all, great fresh food for a great price! make sure if u want the peking duck to order 24hrs in advance. the beggars chicken must be preordered 48 hours in advance. they slow cook it with stuffed with sticky rice in banana leaf for 22 hours!  The owner, Jack also serves you and a really nice guy!

Save yourself a trip if you're here for authentic Chinese food and the Peking duck. The "Chinese food" served here is beyond Americanized, even compared to Panda Express. But hey, we are in the U.S. so that's totally understandable. Now onto the duck, it was a major disappointment because if this is the best duck we've got in Dallas, then I guess I might as well crossing Peking duck off my to-eat list going forward. All dishes I've tried ( 2 separate trips with over 10+ dishes ordered) are all on the overly salty and sweet side, and they just taste like they have the same base sauce no matter what you order. I would have given the place a non-star as a Chinese restaurant, but judging from its patron group it seems like its flavor suits the American taste buds hence the 2 stars.

Our waitress was okay, but honestly that is normal for any Chinese restaurant. I grew up eating at the same chinese restaurant  for 30 years. I moved to texas a couple of years ago and haven't bothered to look for a replacement...Chinese food is not a hot item out here. So glad i came here for the Peking Duck.  I love Duck and this did not disappoint.  Perfect crispy skin and super tender meat.  The the stir fried pieces were awesome.  The prices were sinfully low, usually i paid twice this much in Los Angeles for great Chinese food. BYOB saves you another 25% on your bill. The guy that runs the place was super nice.  The decor is lacking and there are a lot of large loud families, but i am still looking forward to going back.  The only people that should be questioning the authenticity should be from china. I am from the san gabriel valley which is 75% asian, and this was pretty darn good.

You've never had Peking Duck until you've been to Mr. Wok. They only use the best duck and the skin is cooked to that tasty crispy perfection. I've been there multiple times and the Peking Duck never dissappoints. You should definitely arrive hungry. Their portions are good. The Peking duck is a two course meal that just keeps on giving and giving. Make sure you order the duck 24 hours in advance.

If you want to eat here do this immediately:1) Call and make a reservation2) Reserve a duck early in the day3) BYOBThis place is a complete mad house at night and if you don't have a reservation, you are not going to sit down.  In fact, you will stand and be bumped into by waiters and waitresses.  But, if you do sit down and order some food - this place is magical and you forget the surroundings.  Best Peking duck in town.  However, I am going to take off 1 star for the spicy parmesan shrimp because it cost something like $16 and we received.... about 7 small (though tasty) pieces on a giant bed of lettuce.  Come on people.

My husband & I were introduced to this restaurant by our Chinese friends.  The food was authentic and good.  The place was packed but the service was quick.  We had the Peking Duck after reading all the reviews on Yelp.  It was good.  We will definitely go back there soon.

My Japanese wife has spent the past six months scouring the Metroplex for her favorite dish - Ramen.  When she first came home from this restaurant she smiled to me and said "I found it!."On my trip here we had calamari, ramen, Asian spaghetti, and Japanese chahan (fried rice.)  The calamari was good and we enjoyed the sauce.  The ramen was good.  (So good that my wife suggests this restaurant almost every time we consider going out.)  The chahan really tasted Japanese.  I would be surprised if someone in this family hasn't spent a significant amount of time in Japan.     On a side note, this place was established by a father and passed down to a son.  I've seen lace of inter-generational talent ruin so many fine family businesses that I am impressed when it is done well.  I never ate here when the father was still in charge, but the son does things really well. Kudos.

I visited Mr. Wok today for lunch on the recommendation of my fellow Yelpers.  That and the fact that it's almost close enough to my office to walk.I probably ordered the wrong thing... I got the Hunan Chicken with Fried Rice & Pork Eggroll.  The food was good, although from the cute little pepper next to the item I ordered... I expected some heat.  There was no heat at all...even my fellow wimpy mouths could have eaten it.I also noticed that the patrons of Asian decent were given a 2nd menu from which to select their meals... I was only offered the regular menu.  There were quite a few people eating from large bowls full of broth and noodles, so I believe I need to go back and try something else.At 1205pm this place was packed today.. and the only open table was a huge round table designed for an 8top with a lazy susan.  I was also a tad turned off by the fact that I had to walk to the "expo counter" in order to pay.  Seriously... people don't need to be standing at the counter watching the waitress fill plates with rice.
Excellent Chinese! Family owned. Orange peel beef is out of this world. My favorite spot for lunch.

Their cha han is hands down the best fried rice in the metroplex. I first sought this place out because I had heard it had good ramen (pre-Ajisen era).  The ramen was fair, but there was nothing particularly notable about it.   And then I tried the cha han-- perfection.  Flavorful without being greasy.  There's actually an entire Japanese menu, but I've never managed to tear myself away to try anything else.
its true that service is great, very friendly .. but food wasnt really that great. or atleast what we tried... vegetable lettuce wrap and peppercorn chicken.

What an amazing Peking Duck.  I had read reviews all week and also on yelp and made my reservation for our duck.  It did NOT disappoint!!  Probably the best Peking Duck I have ever had...ever.  Our group of 4 arrived hungry at 11:30 and by 11:45 the place was full of diners.  Nearly everyone had the duck and it was just amazing...juicy meat, crispy skin, hot tortillas to wrap it all up.  And the most amazing was the soup afterwards made with the remaining duck bones.  Did not expect it to be anything special and it was awesome with flavor.  We tried the sampler appetizers and they were very delicious as well as the green beans that were smoky and very flavorful--a perfect counterpoint to the rich duck.  We will be regulars from now on!  YUM!

If you like American Chinese this place is better than the rest.  If you like real Asian food there are many better places in Greenville Ave.  Everyone seems to like the Peking Duck, which I didn't try, but one dish doesn't make a restaurant.  I really wanted to like this place but it failed my test, I was in the majority, i.e., there were more non-Asians than Asians eating. Very, very ordinary!

As far as local mom and pop places, it doesnt get any better...we met friends for dinner and had ordered several items:  fried tofu, edamame, water spinach with garlic- all terrific!  I am vegetarian, so the rest of the table shared peking duck, then  sesame chicken, pork with salted vegetables, mango shrimp and a sauteed peking duck dish with the "carcass"- all looked phenominal.  everything was so fresh and you get huge quantities to go home with.   At 8 PM on a Thursday we got the last parking spot and the last table- this place is a gem

The low review is for the atmosphere, not the food.   The food was amazing but I would recommend take out only unless you are with a large group that can make a reservation.   Without one, expect a 30 minute to 1.5 hour wait during peak dinner times.   I was there with my boyfriend and after a  30 minute wait, we were finally seated at a small table for two in the middle of the dining area right in the path of the wait staff.   We spent most of the evening ducking whenever the wait staff came thru as the area was so crowded they literally had to bump into us and hold the trays over our heads to make it to other tables.   The servers seemed to cater to the large groups.  I think we spent about 15-20 minutes waiting for someone to take our drink order.

Having read the reviews of other yelpers and having just finished watching bangkok dangerous (a terrible move) we had a hankering for asian cuisine and headed to Mr. Wok on many positive reviews.We had a mix of japanese and standard chinese food that was all well prepared and served quickly. We got there early, around 6pm, and watched as the restaurant filled up with regulars by 7pm. We had dumplings, potstickers, orange beef and ramen noodles,  watching a movie that bad made us pretty hungry. We also got a pork egg roll and a cinnamon beef egg roll as i've never heard of or tried a cinnamon beef egg roll.The dumplings and potstickers were good but I'm not sure if they are made in house, I still prefer jeng chi in richardson if I need a dumpling fix.The orange beef was good flavorful but not overly sweet or spicy. The Ton Chung ramen soup was very good and very filling. I will say that the orange beef is served a single serving portion and not the heaping platter you will normally get at a chinese restaurant so if your planing on sharing make sure you order enough.The pork egg roll was your standard egg roll and very good. The cinnamon beef egg roll was good, but different. It a sweetness that the cinnamon provided that I can't saw I look forward to having again but I wouldn't refuse it if someone offered it for free.All in all, it was a nice meal and close to big M little urphy  and we would go back again.
This place is really an under appreciated gem.  They have great flavors, courteous service.  I love the mushu chicken and the duck and authentic ramen noodles for lunch.

I've had amazing Chinese food in San Francisco, Los Angeles and New York and this place is up there with the best. The food is fresh and inventive and the service is flawless. I couldn't recommend it more.
Our favorite Asian food by far. We've been coming here for years. Try the specialties and avoid the basic stuff. Crispy tangy beef, mango shrimp, and Thai curry are the best. It's great food.

This one is real easy. The food here is very good.  First, the edamame is seared on Mr. Woks Wok and has a great taste.  Second the calamari was as good as anything I have tasted in Spain or Italy.  The pot stickers were some of the best in the city.  The Duck?  The Peking Duck was simply brilliant.  Carved at your table and the bones are then used to make stir fry and or soup.  We did both and they were great.  I highly recommend Mr. Wok.

I've gone to Mr. Wok more than a handful of times & have always had a great experience. By far the highlight is the Peking duck since this restaurant's known for it in the Chinese community. Remember to request this at least 24-hours in advance so they can have plenty of time to prepare it. Then again, he usually has a few extra's just in case. The calamari appetizer's just the right texture to start off your meal. The hot & sour soup (family recipe from what Jack said) is tasty as well. Also, the mango shrimp is indeed flavorful. Checkout their variation of edamame with soy sauce (wok seared) along with the Beggars chicken (whole chicken stuffed with sticky rice & then the chicken's wrapped in dough). When you're in the mood for something soupy, I'd recommend one of their Japanese/Chinese noodle soups. Soft noodles & tender meats yet so healthy with all the vegetables along with the flavorful broth.Along with great food, there's also great service especially from the owner, Jack. He not only wants to make sure your food's flavorful & delicious, but also your overall experience is pleasant. It has to be good if little elementary school kids are writing to thank him! :-p Every time I've gone there, he always has a big smile on his face regardless if the place's busy or not. That's always a good thing to see right when you walk into a restaurant.
Great peking duck, can't say that any other dish that i've had is worth mentioning.  would like to try the beggars chicken some time.

We went with friends who are regulars here. I am so glad we did. It's hard to find good Chinese food in a city that is being taken over by poor buffets. Mr. Wok is in a class by itself. Our dinner was great from appetizers to dessert. We had edamame, dumplings, and crab rangoon. All were better than anything we've had lately. All the dinners were delicious. I know this because we all had to stick our forks in everybody else's meal. You can't help yourself, because the presentations are enticing. Not fancy, but a lot of eye appeal. Dessert was a yummy banana and chocolate chip roll. It was fried to perfection. Not a drop of oil on the plate. The kitchen is more than willing to adjust recipes to meet dietary needs. My husband and I did not leave a crumb on our plates .As an added bonus the prices are very reasonable and the restaurant is BYOB. Service is outstanding.  I highly recommend Mr. Wok.

This place is awsome. I believe they recently remodeled and are now calling it Mr Wok Asian Bistro.  The inside is much nice than the outside leads you to believe.  Great ambience.  The food is excellent. My favorite dish that I get every time since I was a teenager is the Seasame Chicken. They do it really well here.  I am an adventerous eater so when I eat Seasame Chicken at a place with regularity that is saying something.  Go Mr Wok...and the owner are cool for sure.

I admit that I had my doubts coming into this place. Coming from California, I would say that my standards for Chinese food are also pretty high. Still, Mr. Wok surprised me.We ordered the edamame, yaki soba, and peking duck. The edamame, traditionally boiled, was stir fried. It brought out the aroma of the soy beans but also took away from the nutritional value. The yaki soba was terrible: soggy, sloppy, and mixed with the wrong sauce. The peking duck is one of the restaurant's specialties. So special that you must call in and reserve one--first time I had heard of this.The duck is brought to you fresh from the oven and carved table-side. First the skin, then the meat. The remaining parts can be either stir-fried or made into soup. We chose the former, and the experience is akin to eating ribs. Meanwhile, the meat and skin are mixed into a pancake (think tortilla) with oyster sauce and green onions. Overall, this was definitely the highlight of the meal. The duck was large, flavorful, and well-prepared. If I had to nit-pick, I would say that it was a tad dry.Service was very good on a day when the house was full. Oh, and this place is BYOB. And the owner's a cool guy.

Mr. Wok better Wok himself over to Asia. The food was OK. I mean OK, nothing special but definitely cleared my plate. I ordered the sesame tofu and the flavors were right but not the texture. when cooking tofu in replacement of meat you normally batter it then fry it so there is some crispness to the pallet. At least in my standards. I love Asian cuisine of all types and am excited to try their pad Thai. A nice plus to this establishment is that you can sub out meat for tofu in any of their dishes. The tofu appetizer was cooked well, now only if they could incorporate that into some other dishes. I sound like a broken record, tofu, tofu, tofu, come on guys give me a few more options on your menu. I realize veggies aren't prevalent in TX but at least Cwok down the street had a pho-duck. On another note, It could of been the fact that i had take out but the portion was kind of small for 6 bucks. Overall I will probably eat there again but I won't be going out of my way for it.
Awesome Peking duck and mango shrimp! Not pretentious and just a great restaurant with good food.
Best Chinese in Dallas / try pot stickers and mango shrimp // this place is the opposite of a PF Chang's in the sense its real good not chain Chinese food.
definitely one of the best bowls of ramen in town!
We heart Mr Wok!  Owners Jack and Amanda are a lovely couple and so much fun to hang out with! We love love the shrimp with mango dish. So good. We're definitely going back again and again and again

Went to Mr. Wok for the first time, we were seated promptly but were not served at all for over 1/2 an hour!  We were actually ignored while the staff fussed over another customer right next to us.  We saw entrees being served, condiments given, tea refilled all the while being ignored.  Finally someone came to us saying they were not a wait-staff, but had we been served, we said no, they apologized and we ordered appetizers.  We ordered salt and pepper calamari and hot and sour soup.  The soup was cold and the calamari was chewy, we should have known better and just left but we ordered anyway.  All the dishes tasted the same with one exception, the shrimp and mango which was outstanding.  Too bad the service was horrific, we will never go back again and we left no tip as this was the only recourse we had against such terrible service.  Shame on Mr. Wok for being so indifferent. I have never written a review before bit felt compelled to do so now because I would have given this establishment years of dutiful patronage if only they cared enough for every customer.
